Esto, aunado a la manera en que el Senado ha sido incapaz de definir un Fiscal AnticorrupciÃ³n desde 2014, lo cual provocÃ³ que el Sistema Nacional AnticorrupciÃ³n que por ley debÃ­a entrar en funciones el 19 de julio pasado, iniciara operaciones de manera acÃ©fala.

TEXT:
Â¿QuiÃ©n fiscalizarÃ¡ el 2018? Es la pregunta que ronda en cÃ­rculos polÃ­ticos, luego de que la AuditorÃ­a Superior de la FederaciÃ³n (ASF) se sumarÃ¡ a la lista de instituciones fiscalizadoras sin titular ante la confrontaciÃ³n electoral del prÃ³ximo aÃ±o: la ProcuradurÃ­a General de la RepÃºblica, la FiscalÃ­a Especializada para la AtenciÃ³n de Delitos Electorales (Fepade) y el Sistema Nacional AnticorrupciÃ³n.

El auditor Juan Manuel Portal concluirÃ¡ su gestiÃ³n en diciembre prÃ³ximo, tras ocho aÃ±os al frente de la ASF. Una situaciÃ³n que ha generado dudas sobre los tÃ©rminos en que la CÃ¡mara de Diputados habrÃ¡ de definir al relevo del auditor, justo en medio de la rebatinga polÃ­tica que provocÃ³ la destituciÃ³n de Santiago Nieto como titular de la Fepade o la caÃ­da de RaÃºl Cervantes como procurador y futuro Fiscal General.

Esto, aunado a la manera en que el Senado ha sido incapaz de definir un Fiscal AnticorrupciÃ³n desde 2014, lo cual provocÃ³ que el Sistema Nacional AnticorrupciÃ³n que por ley debÃ­a entrar en funciones el 19 de julio pasado, iniciara operaciones de manera acÃ©fala.

"Si no hay condiciones para definir a alguien que tenga el perfil idÃ³neo para esa responsabilidad, creo que difÃ­cilmente estaremos en condiciones para definir un fiscal, tendremos que esperar a que ocurra la elecciÃ³n de julio del prÃ³ximo aÃ±o, para que entonces se decante un poco la efervescencia y busquemos realmente algo distinto", dijo el presidente Enrique PeÃ±a Nieto en octubre pasado, tras reconocer que no existen condiciones para nombrar a un futuro Fiscal General.

Un escenario similar al que se vive en el Senado, donde la alianza PRI-PVEM y la oposiciÃ³n conformada por PAN, PRD y PT-Morena, se han reprochado mutuamente querer imponer un fiscal electoral a modo, previo a los comicios de 2018.

De ahÃ­ que la elecciÃ³n de un nuevo auditor resulta vital dentro del ajedrez polÃ­tico del aÃ±o entrante, pues tal como ha reconocido la AuditorÃ­a, alrededor del 66% de los recursos estatales se desvÃ­an a campaÃ±as electorales.

Ante la nueva crisis que se avecina, los partidos polÃ­ticos en la CÃ¡mara de Diputados consideran la posibilidad de reelegir a Portal en el cargo, ante los resultados arrojados por su gestiÃ³n al frente de la ASF.

Una posibilidad que el mismo Portal MartÃ­nez tiene en mente, al reconocer su intenciÃ³n de "aventarse" un segundo periodo como titular de la AuditorÃ­a, siempre y cuando la propuesta provenga de los diputados.

"No es que se aviente uno. Â¿Sabe quÃ©? O me avientan. Yo no puedo estar buscando, yo termino. Yo tengo un nombramiento, un mandato que termina el 31 de diciembre, asÃ­ termina, asÃ­ fue lo que aceptÃ©. Si la CÃ¡mara de Diputados quiere hacer otra cosa, que me avisen", indicÃ³.

Ante la insistencia de los reporteros, Portal dejÃ³ abierta la posibilidad de un segundo mandato en caso de ser nominado por los diputados.

"La AuditorÃ­a Superior de la FederaciÃ³n es, el dÃ­a de hoy, mÃ¡s sÃ³lida, mÃ¡s confiable y mÃ¡s reconocida que hace ocho aÃ±os. El trabajo desempeÃ±ado ha valido la pena", dijo Portal al entregar el Ãºltimo informe de auditorÃ­a de su gestiÃ³n.

"Tras ocho aÃ±os de actividades, podemos afirmar que MÃ©xico cuenta con un ente fiscalizador muy distinto al de 2009, cuando iniciÃ© mi gestiÃ³n como Auditor Superior de la FederaciÃ³n. Fue mi propÃ³sito hacer un relanzamiento de esta instituciÃ³n, a partir de las bases creadas en el periodo 2002-2009, con el fin de llegar hasta el lÃ­mite de nuestras atribuciones legales, en aras de impulsar el perfeccionamiento de la gestiÃ³n gubernamental", agregÃ³.

"El reto que enfrentamos dÃ­a a dÃ­a se mantiene, mÃ¡s allÃ¡ de quiÃ©n tenga a su cargo la conducciÃ³n de esta organizaciÃ³n, por lo que espero que el compromiso que se ha manifestado hasta el momento, se profundice e intensifique a travÃ©s de mantener una actitud profesional, abierta a la autocrÃ­tica y que tenga como fin mejorar, de manera continua, su actuaciÃ³n como integrantes de esta gran organizaciÃ³n", agregÃ³.

Entre los principales avances de su gestiÃ³n, el auditor resaltÃ³ la creaciÃ³n de "una DirecciÃ³n General que se encargara de llevar a cabo auditorÃ­as de tipo forense, con el fin de incluir esta metodologÃ­a entre las alternativas para revisar el ejercicio presupuestal y contar con elementos adicionales que fortaleciesen la identificaciÃ³n de ilÃ­citos".

TITLE: Â¿QuiÃ©n fiscalizarÃ¡ el 2018? La ASF se suma a la guerra polÃ­tica por el control de fiscalÃ­a general, electoral y anticorrupciÃ³n

SUMMARY:
Modi presents the Prince of Bhutan with an official football from the FIFA U-17 World Cup.
ADVERTISEMENTKing Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck and Queen Jetsun Pema Wangchuck are on an official trip to India.
The Crown Prince of Bhutan, Jigme Namgyel Wangchuck, won hearts all around with his cuteness.
And Swaraj wasn't immune to his charm either.
EAM @SushmaSwaraj receives Their Majesties, The King, The Queen and The Gyalsey (Prince) of Bhutan pic.twitter.com/D9rrB2ClFH â€” Raveesh Kumar (@MEAIndia) October 31, 2017Slay, little prince.
TEXT:
Modi presents the Prince of Bhutan with an official football from the FIFA U-17 World Cup.

ADVERTISEMENT

King Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck and Queen Jetsun Pema Wangchuck are on an official trip to India. Right from the airport, where External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj received them, to other official engagements, the star of the moment wasn't the royal couple.

The Crown Prince of Bhutan, Jigme Namgyel Wangchuck, won hearts all around with his cuteness. Born in February, 2016, the little prince was presented with an official football from the FIFA U-17 World Cup and a chess set by Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

As his smiling parents kept an eye on the pint-sized crown prince, he charmed the PM, bowing prettily and eagerly reaching out for the ball.

And Swaraj wasn't immune to his charm either.

Special gesture for a valued friend. EAM @SushmaSwaraj receives Their Majesties, The King, The Queen and The Gyalsey (Prince) of Bhutan pic.twitter.com/D9rrB2ClFH â€” Raveesh Kumar (@MEAIndia) October 31, 2017

Slay, little prince.
TITLE: PHOTOS: India Can't Get Enough Of Bhutan's Incredibly Cute, 2-Year-Old Crown Prince

SUMMARY:
Looking through Facebook today I stumbled upon four wine memes in a row -- gifs with oversized wine glasses, women sobbing comically into wine -- funny and relatable.
What's behind the wine memes is friendship and connection -- we are signalling to friends and colleagues about a shared experience.
Just like the Jack Daniels beanie signifies a person really, really likes Jack Daniels and wants the world to know it; wine memes and coffee cups with 'wine time' on them help us to craft a certain type of identity.
You could almost see the proliferation of wine memes as a new way for people to have a voice.
Wine memes disturb me because they glorify wine.
TEXT:
Looking through Facebook today I stumbled upon four wine memes in a row -- gifs with oversized wine glasses, women sobbing comically into wine -- funny and relatable.

One of them said, "Here's to friends with the same taste in wine, and different tastes in men", with The Golden Girls clinking enormous glasses of red wine together. My friends that posted or tagged each other in these videos all work in mental health; they're smart, insightful, high-achieving people who I respect and admire.

So, why is this a thing, and why does it seem to be so prolific among clever people? A couple of years ago, publicly sharing a wine meme would have been unusual for anyone who had some kind of investment in looking responsible. Promotion of an alcoholic beverage was reserved for people who wore Jack Daniels beanies and had stubby coolers with vaguely sexist statements on them.

Memes have been a relatively recent phenomenon and their success seems to depend on how relatable they are (such as, the recent one of a child being horrified when someone starts eating their chips) and how edgy they can be (memes about drinking, embarrassing drunken scenarios and Tinder would be examples of this).

Memes seem to be a way of representing or symbolising something that is either too boring or too controversial to put into words -- somewhere between a poem and an emoticon. The wine memes that seem to be the most popular always involve drinking to excess, and some kind of extreme display of emotion -- the ultimate representation of what it's like to drink a lot.

What's behind the wine memes is friendship and connection -- we are signalling to friends and colleagues about a shared experience.

One thing's clear, the culture has shifted, perhaps in a good way, towards not caring as much about what others think and being able to share vaguely inappropriate content. Just like the Jack Daniels beanie signifies a person really, really likes Jack Daniels and wants the world to know it; wine memes and coffee cups with 'wine time' on them help us to craft a certain type of identity.

What is a woman who likes wine like? Perhaps she is busy, overworked, stressed out. Perhaps she needs some 'me time' and wine is the best way to achieve this. You could almost see the proliferation of wine memes as a new way for people to have a voice. But what exactly are we saying?

"I'm exhausted and having a terrible week, but I don't want to share that because nobody really wants to hear it."

Or: "I really love wine because it gives me the opportunity to take some time for myself after I've given everything to my family, friends and work."

Or: "I love spending time with my friends and getting really silly after a couple of wines, and I want to remind them of how much fun we had."

The wine memes themselves aren't really the problem. It is obvious from the women tagging other women -- friends, colleagues, family -- that it's a way to connect, a way to say "I miss you" or "let's hang out" or "remember when we had that awesome night". What's behind the wine memes is friendship and connection -- we are signalling to friends and colleagues about a shared experience.

And if it's about that, why let wine take all the credit? Yes, it was there at the time -- and perhaps lowered your inhibitions enough so that you could have deep and meaningful conversations with friends. But so was music, and probably French onion dip, and likely some kind of couch -- and we don't make couch memes. As we know, wine by itself, in bad company, is just wine. It is the people behind the experiences that are a make or break.

Wine memes disturb me because they glorify wine. Wine is just a bunch of off-grapes that cause our brains to release chemicals which turn wine into something that we worship, think about, talk about. Wine has become the focus, not the friendships behind it. Our drinking culture is shifting away from drinking to excess, but one group that is actually increasing its alcohol consumption is women between the ages of 21 and 35.

I wouldn't dream of saying down with wine memes. In fact, I find comically large wine glasses as funny as the next person. My point is that it might be helpful to look a bit deeper when we are sharing memes or participating in them.

Perhaps it is saying something about modern female identity, that we make jokes about the sweet embrace of alcohol, while biding our time until 5pm when it feels okay to pour that wine.

Now, more than ever, women have a voice and a platform, one which is growing larger every day. It might be a good time to examine our relationship with alcohol, and figure out why, when the rest of the country is moving away from it, we are gravitating towards it, with open arms and excessive displays of emotion (and oversized wine glasses).

Perhaps it is just that we care less about what people think, and want to live our lives on our terms. Or, perhaps we are trying to say something very important, and don't quite yet have the words to say it.
TITLE: Put A Cork In Your Wine Memes

Aber ich mÃ¶chte euch wirklich sagen: Ich habe groÃŸen Respekt davor, was ihr fÃ¼r Verantwortung zeigt, welchen Mut ihr habt, was ihr euch traut", sagte SÃ¶der an die bayerische JU gerichtet. "Das ist eine Landesversammlung, und es ist eine Junge Union, die zeigt RÃ¼ckgrat in der Partei. Meinen Respekt davor, toll gemacht."

Die MenÂ­schen haben ein feiÂ­nes GeÂ­spÃ¼r dafÃ¼r, dass der AnÂ­stand geÂ­wahrt bleiÂ­ben muss. GeÂ­raÂ­de ein MiÂ­nisÂ­terÂ­prÃ¤Â­siÂ­dent ist eine ReÂ­spektsÂ­perÂ­son."

SUMMARY:
ANC secretary-general Gwede Mantashe said Buthelezi had "run his race and played his role".
While acknowledging Buthelezi's role in the violence of the 1980s and 1990s, Holomisa also praised him for calling off the dogs of war.
Holomisa wished him a "well-deserved rest".
Buthelezi's role in South Africa's history should never be sanitised.
These are just a few of the places associated with massacres carried out by Buthelezi's party in collaboration with the apartheid state.
TEXT:
Some time ago, I decided to refrain from writing about Mangosuthu Buthelezi until after old age had dealt him the fate that he and his murderous battalions prematurely dealt others. That was mainly because so much has been said and written -- including by this lowly newspaperman -- about the evil legacy of the head of the Inkatha Freedom Party.

Even when he made his long-overdue announcement about his imminent retirement, I was determined to resist the temptation to write about him. But then came the disingenuous tributes. ANC secretary-general Gwede Mantashe said Buthelezi had "run his race and played his role". DA leader Mmusi Maimane thanked him "for the role he played in KwaZulu-Natal in the early 1990s" -- which happens to be when the IFP's bloodlust was at its peak. He expressed appreciation "for the 1994 decision Buthelezi took to participate in the first democratic South African election after he initially refused".

Wow!

After the man and his friends in the loony right-wing and the security forces waged a terror campaign against the people with their machine guns, bombs and other weapons, we are supposed to be grateful. But the one that took the cake was a tribute penned by United Democratic Movement leader Bantu Holomisa.

While acknowledging Buthelezi's role in the violence of the 1980s and 1990s, Holomisa also praised him for calling off the dogs of war. "His astute leadership qualities became evident as he helped resolve the situation," Holomisa wrote.

Help me here. Someone starts a fire and then gets praised when he joins community efforts to douse the flames? Holomisa continued: "Shenge was very influential at the negotiating table during Codesa [the Convention for a Democratic SA]. His vision and commitment could not be ignored."

True.

If only Buthelezi's praise singers could pause and repeat these names: Boipatong, Shobashobane, KwaMakhutha, Sebokeng, Khumalo Street, KwaThema, Meadowlands, Trust Feed, Hammarsdale, Swanieville and Imbali.

He was indeed influential in demanding a semi-autonomous Zulu kingdom and using violence to force his point across. Who could ignore such mayhem and destruction? The general then lectured that Buthelezi's political life "teaches us that, to be a formidable leader, you never shy away from your responsibility to the nation for empty populist slogans".

Again, true.

The people of KwaZulu-Natal and Gauteng know exactly what a formidable leader he is -- not because of empty populist slogans, but because of the time they spent at funerals. In his message, Mantashe wished Buthelezi "a good retirement". Maimane wished him "strength in retirement" and "many years of good health". Holomisa wished him a "well-deserved rest".

If only the dead, the orphans, the widows, widowers and the countless victims of Buthelezi's insatiable bloodlust could also have been wished such.

Egregious sins

I know it is human instinct to be nice to the elderly to the point of grossly misrepresenting the truth. This seems to be the case with Buthelezi, who has suddenly become everyone's favourite grandfather figure. Buthelezi's role in South Africa's history should never be sanitised. Of all the Bantustan leaders who collaborated with the apartheid regime, he was the worst.

His fellow travellers, such as Lucas Mangope, Lennox Sebe, Patrick Mphephu and Kaiser Matanzima, were brutal in their collaboration and suppression of anti-apartheid activism. They served the apartheid government with the enthusiasm of a strip-club janitor who loves his job because it gives him benefits he would otherwise not have enjoyed.

But none of them was as dedicated to upholding and defending the apartheid system as Buthelezi. So much so that the National Party government's security apparatus armed and gave logistical support to the killers who proliferated in his party. Elite IFP killer squads and militias were trained by the South African military in camps inside and outside South Africa.

If only Buthelezi's praise singers could pause and repeat these names: Boipatong, Shobashobane, KwaMakhutha, Sebokeng, Khumalo Street, KwaThema, Meadowlands, Trust Feed, Hammarsdale, Swanieville and Imbali. These are just a few of the places associated with massacres carried out by Buthelezi's party in collaboration with the apartheid state.

It is important that, while he lives, Buthelezi is reminded of his egregious sins.

These imbongis should tell those in South Africa's townships and villages who were terrorised by IFP impis that this man truly deserves a peaceful retirement. It is a tribute to the great spirit of South Africans that Buthelezi -- like his surviving masters in the erstwhile National Party leadership -- can enjoy the comfort of the democratic South Africa they fought so hard and bloodily to stop.

We can be certain that this parade of tributes will be repeated when Buthelezi sheds his mortal coil. The revisionism will be strong as people make the excuse that culture says this and tradition says that. We will only be told of his greatness and not the evil that he perpetrated.

So it is important that, while he lives, Buthelezi is reminded of his egregious sins. History behoves us to parade before him the images of the corpses of those who died because he committed troops to the defence of apartheid. As he rocks in his retirement chair in Mahlabathini, he has to be haunted by his deeds.

No rest for this cantankerous chief.

This post first appeared in the City Press on November 5, 2017.
TITLE: Butheleziâ€™s Role In SA History Should Never Be Sanitised

TEXT:
Nordkorea war das dominierende Thema beim Treffen von Donald Trump und Japans Premierminister Shinzo Abe

Trump sagte: "Die Ã„ra der strategischen Geduld" sei zu Ende

Donald Trump hat seine Position bezÃ¼glich Nordkorea bekrÃ¤ftigt. Die Ã„ra strategischer Geduld sei vorbei, sagte der US-PrÃ¤sident.

"Wenn die Leute sagen, meine Rhetorik sei zu stark, sollten wir uns ansehen, wohin wir mit schwacher Rhetorik in den vergangenen 25 Jahren gekommen sind", sagte Trump am Montag in Tokio bei einer gemeinsamen Pressekonferenz mit Japans Premier Shinzo Abe.

Maximaler Druck auf PjÃ¶ngjang

Der japanische Regierungschef beteuerte ebenfalls, dass Japan und die USA im Konflikt um Nordkoreas Atom- und Raketenprogramm den Druck auf PjÃ¶ngjang erhÃ¶hen wollten. Dies sei nicht die Zeit fÃ¼r Dialog mit Nordkorea.

"Dialog um des Dialoges willen mache keinen Sinn", sagte Abe. "Wir wollen durch alle mÃ¶glichen Mittel den Druck auf Nordkorea bis zum Maximalen erhÃ¶hen."

Konkret kÃ¼ndigte Abe an, die Sanktionen auszuweiten: Die VermÃ¶genswerte von 35 nordkoreanischen Gruppierungen und Einzelpersonen sollen eingefroren werden. Mit dieser Strategie wollen die VerbÃ¼ndeten den andauernden Nukleartests des nordkoreanischen Regimes Einhalt gebieten.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Medienbericht: Trump kritisiert vor Asien-Reise Japans Umgang mit Nordkorea

Trump verteidigt RÃ¼ckzug aus Handelsabkommen TPP

Trump verteidigte in Japan auch den RÃ¼ckzug der USA aus dem transpazifischen Handelsabkommen TPP. Bei einem Treffen mit GeschÃ¤ftsleuten sagte Trump am Montagmorgen (Ortszeit) in Tokio: "Wir werden mehr Handel haben als im Rahmen von TPP, und die Situation wird viel weniger komplex sein." TPP sei nicht die richtige Idee gewesen.

TPP sollte rund um den Pazifik die grÃ¶ÃŸte Freihandelszone der Welt schaffen. Der Vertrag war im Februar 2016 unterzeichnet worden, aber noch nicht in Kraft getreten. Die elf Handelspartner reprÃ¤sentieren 800 Millionen Menschen und 40 Prozent der Weltwirtschaft. Sie wollen nach dem RÃ¼ckzug der USA groÃŸenteils ohne Amerika weiter vorangehen.

"Der Handel mit Japan ist nicht frei und er ist nicht gegenseitig, aber er wird es bald sein", sagte Trump. Er habe keinen Zweifel, dass dies fair geschehen werde. Es werde eine Zeit dauern, aber dann werde es Handelsdeals und "Handelskonzepte" geben.

Entsprechende GesprÃ¤che mit Japan dauerten schon sehr lange. Das finanzielle Ergebnis werde besser fÃ¼r beide LÃ¤nder sein. In den vergangenen Jahrzehnten habe Japan in Handelsfragen mit den USA immer gewonnen, sagte Trump.



(ll)
TITLE: Trump Ã¼ber Nordkorea: "Die Ã„ra der strategischen Geduld ist zu Ende"

TEXT:
Ein Autofahrer hat in Berlin RettungskrÃ¤fte wÃ¤hrend eines Einsatzes attackiert. (Symbolbild) | iStock

Ein 23-JÃ¤hriger hat einen Rettungseinsatz in Berlin behindert

Er regte sich darÃ¼ber auf, dass sein Auto eingeparkt war

Bei dem Einsatz ging es um ein einjÃ¤hriges Kind, das wiederbelebt werden musste

Es ist eine dieser Meldungen, die fÃ¼r empÃ¶rtes KopfschÃ¼tteln sorgen.

Am Freitag hat sich ein 23-JÃ¤hriger in Berlin mit Polizei und RettungskrÃ¤ften angelegt, weil sie sein Auto zugeparkt hatten. Die SanitÃ¤ter waren gerade dabei, einen einjÃ¤hrigen Jungen zu reanimieren, der in seiner Kita im Stadtteil Moabit beim Spielen plÃ¶tzlich ohnmÃ¤chtig geworden war.

Laut einem Bericht der "Bild"-Zeitung stellte der Notarzt bei dem Kleinen Kammerflimmern fest und musste ihn an Ort und Stelle wiederbeleben.

"Mir doch egal, wer hier gerade reanimiert wird"

Dass es hier um das Leben eines Kleinkindes ging, scheint dem 23-jÃ¤hrigen RÃ¼pel allerdings herzlich wenig interessiert zu haben. "Mir doch egal, wer hier gerade reanimiert wird", soll er laut "Bild" zu den Polizeibeamten gesagt haben, die ebenfalls angerÃ¼ckt waren.

Und das, obwohl die Lage vÃ¶llig offensichtlich gewesen zu sein scheint. "Ich habe ihm erklÃ¤rt, dass wir gerade ein Kind reanimieren und den Rettungswagen jetzt nicht wegfahren kÃ¶nnen", zitiert die "Bild" einen der SanitÃ¤ter. "Doch der hat sich drohend vor mir aufgebaut, als ob er gleich zuschlagen will."

Feuerwehr erstattet Anzeige gegen den Mann

AuÃŸerdem soll der Mann gebrÃ¼llt haben: "Verpisst euch, ich muss zur Arbeit." Laut der "Berliner Zeitung" wurde der Mann zudem handgreiflich und trat den Seitenspiegel des Rettungswagens ab.

Erst als die Polizisten den Mann in Schach hielten, konnten die SanitÃ¤ter demnach ihre Arbeit fortsetzen und das Kind reanimieren. Der EinjÃ¤hrige wurde auf die Kinderintensivstation gebracht, gegen den Mann hat die Feuerwehr Anzeige erstattet.

TEXT:
Donald Trump hat den Bundesstaat Hawaii besucht

Zahlreiche Demonstranten begrÃ¼ÃŸten den US-PrÃ¤sidenten

Ein Spruch fand sich auf ihren Plakaten immer wieder: "Willkommen in Kenia"

â€œDanke fÃ¼r den herzlichen Empfang, Hawaii!â€ schrieb Donald Trump am Samstag auf Twitter. Der US-PrÃ¤sident hatte den Bundesstaat auf seinem Weg nach Asien besucht. Was er in seinem Tweet allerdings unerwÃ¤hnt lieÃŸ: Seine Ankunft auf der Pazifikinsel war von massiven Protesten begleitet worden.

Wie es sich fÃ¼r ordentliche Demonstranten gehÃ¶rt, hatten die Hawaiianer originelle Plakate gebastelt. Ein Video, das die Twitter Userin Kate Ozawa aus ihrem Auto aufnahm, zeigt eine Gruppe von Demonstranten in Honolulu, die den Satz â€œWish you werenâ€™t hereâ€ â€“ "Wir wÃ¼nschten, Sie wÃ¤ren nicht hier" â€“ bilden, in Anlehnung an den beliebten Postkartenspruch â€œWish you were hereâ€.

Trump Protest at the State Capitol. There were like three pro-trump people lol #hawaiij20 #hawaii pic.twitter.com/NpmtOzX2jE â€” Kate Ozawa (@AlohaKatie) November 4, 2017

Eine Frau bemerkte zudem, Trump mache einen derart schlechten Job als PrÃ¤sident, dass selbst George W. Bush dagegen gut weg kÃ¤me.

"Welcome to Kenya!" A growing crowd protests Trump by Honolulu state capitol during his visit to Honolulu pic.twitter.com/KnTeFJSvf2 â€” Jaweed Kaleem ğŸ¦… (@jaweedkaleem) November 4, 2017

Ein Spruch fand sich auf vielen der Plakate: â€œWillkommen in Kenia."

â€Willkommen in Keniaâ€: Was steckt dahinter?

Der Bundesstaat Hawaii gilt seit Jahren als Hochburg der Demokraten. 62 Prozent der Einwohner stimmten bei der letzten US-Wahl fÃ¼r Hillary Clinton. Barack Obama konnte bei den vorangegangenen Wahlen sogar ein Ã¼berwÃ¤ltigendes Ergebnis von jeweils 71 Prozent einfahren, nicht zuletzt, weil Obama auf Hawaii geboren wurde.

Es gibt allerdings einige Amerikaner, die das nie glauben wollten â€“ allen voran Donald Trump.

Eine â€œextrem glaubwÃ¼rdige Quelleâ€ habe in seinem BÃ¼ro angerufen und ihm erzÃ¤hlt, dass Barack Obamas Geburtsurkunde gefÃ¤lscht sei, schrieb Trump 2012 auf Twitter und wurde damit zum RedefÃ¼hrer eine Gruppe von VerschwÃ¶rungstheoretikern, die glauben, Obama sei in Wirklichkeit in Kenia geboren.

Dann hÃ¤tte Obama keine Berechtigung gehabt, sich um das Amt des US-PrÃ¤sidenten zu bewerben, denn die Verfassung sieht vor, dass nur Personen, die in den Vereinigten Staaten geboren wurden, PrÃ¤sident werden kÃ¶nnen.

An 'extremely credible source' has called my office and told me that @BarackObama's birth certificate is a fraud. â€” Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 6, 2012

Die Plakate der Demonstranten spielen mit diesem Irrglauben: Willkommen in der Heimat von Barack Obama, willkommen, also, in Kenia.

Auf dem MarinestÃ¼tzpunkt angekommen, besuchte der US-PrÃ¤sident das Wrack der USS Arizona. Das Kriegsschiff kenterte beim Angriff der Japaner auf Pearl Harbour am 7. Dezember 1941. Die Leichen der sich darin befindenden Soldaten sind noch immer im Bug des Schiffes eingeschlossen. Trump ehrte die Gefallenen, indem er weiÃŸe BlÃ¼tenblÃ¤tter ins Wasser streute.

AnschlieÃŸend reisten er und seine Frau Melania weiter nach Japan.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Trump Ã¼ber Nordkorea: "Die Ã„ra der strategischen Geduld ist zu Ende"

Dieser Text erschien zuerst bei der britischen Ausgabe der HuffPost und wurde Ã¼bersetzt und editiert von Anna Rinderspacher,

One man on Manus Island has been tweeting out what's going on, as roughly 600 men have been left without power, food and water in the government-run detention centre.
Behrouz Boochani, an Iranian refugee who was a journalist before he fled his country, has been held on Manus Island since August 2014.
Most recently he has been tweeting about a man with "severe kidney stones" who was not receiving medical attention:Refugee on Manus with severe kidney stones, crying from pain.
A refugee with heart pain is here.
â€” Behrouz Boochani (@BehrouzBoochani) November 4, 2017Still waiting for someone to pick up sick refugee & take to ELRTC so IHMS can give treatment.Although no advanced medical equipment in Manus November 4, 2017The refugee with heart problem is in a critical situation.
TEXT:
One man on Manus Island has been tweeting out what's going on, as roughly 600 men have been left without power, food and water in the government-run detention centre.

Behrouz Boochani, an Iranian refugee who was a journalist before he fled his country, has been held on Manus Island since August 2014.

Most recently he has been tweeting about a man with "severe kidney stones" who was not receiving medical attention:

Refugee on Manus with severe kidney stones, crying from pain. Govt obviously violating human rights. I'm witnessing a tragedy, a disaster. November 5, 2017

Before that, he tried to bring attention to the fact that a man with a history of heart problems was not receiving adequate attention for heart pains he was feeling.

We need emergency help. A refugee with heart pain is here. His heart beat is high and he's sweating. â€” Behrouz Boochani (@BehrouzBoochani) November 4, 2017

Still waiting for someone to pick up sick refugee & take to ELRTC so IHMS can give treatment.Although no advanced medical equipment in Manus November 4, 2017

The refugee with heart problem is in a critical situation. He has a history of heart issue. Nobody is here to help â€” Behrouz Boochani (@BehrouzBoochani) November 4, 2017

The situation is critical in Manus.A refugee with heart problem seen by doctor after four & half hours.Such a long time for emergency cases â€” Behrouz Boochani (@BehrouzBoochani) November 4, 2017

Anything bad happen for the refugee with heart pain Australia is responsible. You can not continue to kill people because of medical neglect â€” Behrouz Boochani (@BehrouzBoochani) November 4, 2017

Boochani has also written six pieces for The Guardian since October 27 outlining the circumstances him, and the hundreds of others that remain in the Manus Island detention centre, face.

His most recent piece from November 3 reads:

A missionary on Manus wants to bring food for the refugees but is prevented by the navy. The Australian government insists on starving everyone. I have to eventually make my way to Delta prison. The silent protest begins at five. The mosquitoes of Manus are again ruthless and barbaric. Another tough night awaits. Behrouz Boochani

Boochani was also recently awarded an Amnesty International Australia media award in the print, online and multimedia category.

In response to the conditions faced by Boochani and others on the island, protests were held across Australia yesterday.



In Melbourne, Greens MP Adam Bandt labelled Immigration Minister Peter Dutton a "terrorist" for his treatment of refugees and asylum seekers.

The UN High Commissioner on Human Rights condemned the Australian government for their treatment of asylum seekers on Saturday.
TITLE: One Refugee Has Been Tweeting About What's Going On At Manus And It's Terrifying

ADVERTISEMENTTIRUNELVELI -- The Tirunelveli District Court on Monday granted bail to Cartoonist Bala who was arrested on Sunday for his 'defamatory' caricature on Tamil Nadu Chief Minister Edappadi K. Palanisamy and State Police Commissioner.
The Tamil Nadu police had arrested Bala from Tirunelveli after a defamatory case was registered against him for allegedly portraying the Chief Minister in a distasteful manner.
Bala had allegedly portrayed the chief minister, the state's collector and the police commissioner wearing nothing and covering their private parts with money, while a baby burns in front of them.
The caricature was published after a recent incident where a couple and their two children self- immolated at the collectorate, alleging police inaction on a usury complaint.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

TIRUNELVELI -- The Tirunelveli District Court on Monday granted bail to Cartoonist Bala who was arrested on Sunday for his 'defamatory' caricature on Tamil Nadu Chief Minister Edappadi K. Palanisamy and State Police Commissioner.

The Tamil Nadu police had arrested Bala from Tirunelveli after a defamatory case was registered against him for allegedly portraying the Chief Minister in a distasteful manner.

Bala had allegedly portrayed the chief minister, the state's collector and the police commissioner wearing nothing and covering their private parts with money, while a baby burns in front of them.

The caricature was published after a recent incident where a couple and their two children self- immolated at the collectorate, alleging police inaction on a usury complaint.
TITLE: Arrested For Caricature On Tamil Nadu CM, Cartoonist Bala Gets Bail

TEXT:
Tim Cahill to travel to Honduras for Socceroos' World Cup play-off despite ankle injury

Updated

Socceroos talisman Tim Cahill will make the trip to San Pedro Sula for Australia's World Cup play-off first-leg match against Honduras.

There were concerns the 37-year-old would miss the Honduras leg of the tie due to an ankle injury picked up while playing for Melbourne City on Friday night, but Football Federation Australia (FFA) announced on Sunday morning he would leave a day later than the rest of the squad.

The rest of the players will leave today.

The FFA said Cahill had been cleared of a fracture on Saturday, but would require continued assessment and treatment before any decision would be made about his availability for the match in San Pedro Sula.

"Cahill's delayed departure to Honduras is part of the monitoring and rehabilitation process that has been put in place for an ankle injury that the Melbourne City FC attacker sustained on Friday night while playing in the Hyundai A-League," the FFA said in a statement.

Cahill was forced off in the first half at AAMI Park after landing awkwardly when attempting to hurdle Sydney FC defender Jordi Buijs and was whisked away to hospital for scans.

The FFA also confirmed forward Robbie Kruse would not travel to Honduras due to injury, but would join the squad in Sydney along with Mathew Leckie and Mark Milligan, who are suspended for the first leg.

The home-and-away tie with concludes in Sydney on November 15.

Australia squad for two-leg play-off

Goalkeepers: Mitchell Langerak (Levante, Spain), Mat Ryan (Brighton, England), Danny Vukovic (Genk, Belgium).

Mitchell Langerak (Levante, Spain), Mat Ryan (Brighton, England), Danny Vukovic (Genk, Belgium). Defenders: Aziz Behich (Bursaspor, Turkey), Milos Degenek (Yokohama Marinos, Japan), Alex Gersbach (Rosenborg, Norway), Craig Goodwin (Sparta Rotterdam, Netherlands), Matthew Jurman (Suwon, South Korea), Ryan McGowan (Al Sharjah, UAE), Josh Risdon (Western Sydney Wanderers), Trent Sainsbury (Jiangsu Suning, China), Bailey Wright (Bristol City, England).

"Une arme de guerre"

L'AR-15 est en fait une variante civile du M16, le fusil utilisÃ© dans l'armÃ©e amÃ©ricaine depuis prÃ¨s d'un demi-siÃ¨cle -et bien connu des amateurs de jeux vidÃ©o de tir ou de guerre. "C'est un sujet morbide, mais ces gens-lÃ  vont choisir l'arme qui leur permette de tirer le plus possible, une carabine semi-automatique qui ait de la prÃ©cision, qui soit stable, qui ait un grand chargeur", analyse le lieutenant colonel Ã  la retraite Scott Mann, interrogÃ© par le San Bernardino Sun. TEXT:
The Kingdom of Bhutan is known in part for its picturesque, remote location and its unbelievably adorable 1 1/2-year-old heir apparent .

Prince Jigme is currently the royal coupleâ€™s only son and the heir to the throne. The position of king is currently held by his father, and has been since his grandfather, Jigme Singye Wangchuck abdicated the throne in 2006 for his son to take over responsibility in 2008, says the BBC.

Bhutan became a democratic, constitutional monarchy in 2008. Like the government in the United Kingdom, Bhutanâ€™s king serves as the head of state, while a prime minister oversees the government. The role of the king, then, and eventually Prince Jigme, is and will be â€œprimarily representative, serving to symbolize the unity and integrity of the state at home and abroad,â€ according to Britannica.

King Jigme is widely respected and beloved in Bhutan, and oversaw the countryâ€™s final stages toward a full democracy in 2008. â€œHe travelled extensively around the country encouraging people to take part in the vote â€• in which both main parties competed for power on similar manifestos, utterly loyal to their king,â€ BBC reported at the time. The king and his wife have hosted Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge when they made a trip to the region in April 2016.

The royal familyâ€™s most recent trip, a four-day tour of India that began Tuesday, was thought to be a significant step toward moving forward together after a conflict between India and China over territory in the Doklam peninsula.

â€œIn the aftermath of the Doklam standoff, the kingâ€™s visit could help an exchange of views on the matter at the highest levels in India and Bhutan,â€ Harsh V. Pant, a professor of international relations at Kingâ€™s College in London told Indian website LiveMint.

Check out some of our favorite photos of the prince, including some from his trip to India, below.
TITLE: We All Know The Prince Of Bhutan Is Adorable, But How Powerful Is He?

Or, vu le nombre de paradis fiscaux, c'est loin d'Ãªtre simple. Un paradis fiscal est un pays, ou une juridiction, qui pratique un taux d'imposition sur les sociÃ©tÃ©s, les revenus, ou le patrimoine, trÃ¨s bas, et privilÃ©gie l'opacitÃ© bancaire.

"L'UE est la zone avec la densitÃ© de paradis fiscaux la plus forte", dÃ©plore au HuffPost FranÃ§ois d'Aubert, expert du sujet, prÃ©sident de la Commission d'Ã©valuation du forum mondial sur la fiscalitÃ© de l'OCDE de 2009 Ã  2015.

Gibraltar, les Ã®les de Man, Gersey, Guernesey, mais aussi Chypre, Malte, Monaco, et des pays comme les Pays-bas, le Luxembourg, l'Autriche, la Suisse, sont rangÃ©s dans la catÃ©gorie "paradis fiscal" par l'OCDE.

Big bang fiscal en vue pour 2018

MalgrÃ© tout, la cause avance. Impensable il y a encore quelques annÃ©es, la Suisse a votÃ© la fin du secret bancaire pour les ressortissants Ã©trangers en 2015. Il entrera en application en 2018, comme dans de nombreux autres pays.

L'histoire pourrait mÃªme rendre justice aux dÃ©clarations de Nicolas Sarkozy. En effet, suite au fameux G20 Ã  Londres en 2009, un big bang fiscal va s'opÃ©rer en 2018: une centaine de pays se sont engagÃ©s Ã  communiquer automatiquement des donnÃ©es sur les comptes de rÃ©sidents Ã©trangers.

"Une banque Ã  Singapour sera tenue d'envoyer au fisc franÃ§ais les relevÃ©s de compte de ses ressortissants, se fÃ©licite FranÃ§ois d'Aubert. C'est un systÃ¨me trÃ¨s serrÃ© qui va donner une grande connaissance des circuits financiers". Et ceux qui ne sont pas en rÃ¨gle peuvent dÃ©jÃ  s'attendre Ã  un contrÃ´le fiscal...

Bien sÃ»r, il reste encore beaucoup Ã  faire, comme le montre la question de l'imposition des "GAFA" "Google, Apple, Facebook, Amazon) en Europe. Trouver le consensus n'est pas gagnÃ© d'avance pour harmoniser la fiscalitÃ© des Ã©tats membres.

Quand Apple a Ã©tÃ© condamnÃ© par la justice europÃ©enne Ã  rembourser 13 milliards d'euros d'impÃ´ts Ã  l'Irlande en 2016, l'Irlande a fini poursuivie en octobre pour laxisme par la justice europÃ©enne: le pays ne veut pas recouvrir cette somme, fidÃ¨le Ã  sa politique fiscale.

"Il faut imposer les bÃ©nÃ©fices lÃ  oÃ¹ ils sont rÃ©alisÃ©s, reconnaÃ®t FranÃ§ois d'Aubert. Le sujet avance bien Ã  Bruxelles, mais le combat est dur, Ã  la fois sur la fiscalitÃ© et la concurrence". Une rÃ©sistance Ã  la hauteur d'enjeux qui se comptent en milliards d'euros.

Ã€ voir Ã©galement sur Le HuffPost:
TITLE: Paradise Papers: 10 ans aprÃ¨s la crise financiÃ¨re, pourquoi on n'est toujours pas venu Ã  bout des paradis fiscaux

SUMMARY:
Iâ€™ve come back to my hometown to be able to add to the conversation and share what wealth of knowledge Iâ€™ve received living in other cities.â€â€• Jaque Fragua, 31, artistâ€œI live here in Albuquerque by choice.
Iâ€™m too afraid to leave Albuquerque.â€â€• Rose Jojole, 47, stay-at-home momâ€œI was supposed to move to California, but I changed my mind.
I love Albuquerque.
Itâ€™s very peaceful and beautiful.â€â€• Stephanie Rodgriguez (translated by Lin Marksbury), 28, educational assistantâ€œI moved to Albuquerque because of sign language.
... Warts and all, we love our city and our friends.â€â€• Evelyn Dow, 56, managementâ€œIt just seems like Albuquerque is a good city.â€
TEXT:
Albuquerque was the 22nd stop on HuffPostâ€™s Listen to America road trip. We spoke to locals about why this New Mexico city is home. Hereâ€™s what they had to say:

â€œIâ€™m returning from a stint in LA, New York, around the country really. Iâ€™ve come back to my hometown to be able to add to the conversation and share what wealth of knowledge Iâ€™ve received living in other cities.â€

â€• Jaque Fragua, 31, artist

â€œI live here in Albuquerque by choice. Just closer to my home, Iâ€™m originally from here in the Southwest.â€

â€• Ty Harris, 23, artist

â€œThis is where my people come from, here and in Mexico. ... I came here to be closer to my people, my roots.â€

â€• Lisa Lucero, 53, drummer and union carpenter

â€œI fell in love and I never left. Itâ€™s either love it or hate it. If youâ€™ve never been here at all, the scenery is so breathtakingly different. ... Why would you want to be anywhere else?â€

â€• Paul Mansfield, 69, retired

â€œI love New Mexico. ... When I come back to New Mexico, I literally have joy in my heart.â€

â€• Michael Padilla, 45, business owner

â€œI love it here. Iâ€™m too afraid to leave Albuquerque.â€

â€• Rose Jojole, 47, stay-at-home mom

â€œI was supposed to move to California, but I changed my mind. I wanted to stay close to my family. Iâ€™m very close to my family. ... I love Albuquerque. Itâ€™s very peaceful and beautiful.â€

â€• Stephanie Rodgriguez (translated by Lin Marksbury), 28, educational assistant

â€œI moved to Albuquerque because of sign language. ... I work here in the community now. I love it here.â€

â€• Maila Brock, 39, sign language interpreter

â€œWeâ€™re pretty partial. This is home for us. All of our family is here. ... Warts and all, we love our city and our friends.â€

â€• Evelyn Dow, 56, management

â€œIt just seems like Albuquerque is a good city.â€
TITLE: 'Why Would You Want To Be Anywhere Else?': Meet The People Of Albuquerque

Wieso das keine Sammelklage ist

Der Dieselskandal geht in die nÃ¤chste Runde: Mehr als 15.000 Besitzer manipulierter Dieselwagen haben am Montag Ã¼ber die Internetplattform "myright.de" eine Schadenersatzklage gegen Volkswagen eingereicht. DafÃ¼r fuhren etwa 50 Betroffene gemeinsam in einem Bus am Landgericht Braunschweig vor.

Nach Angaben des Rechtsdienstleisters "myright.de" belÃ¤uft sich die Schadensumme auf mehr als 350 Millionen Euro. FÃ¼r die genau 15.374 GeschÃ¤digten verlange man die RÃ¼ckzahlung des Kaufpreises gegen die RÃ¼ckgabe der Fahrzeuge.

"Deutsche Kunden sind nicht Kunden zweiter Klasse. Sie haben dieselben Rechte und AnsprÃ¼che wie US-Kunden", sagte Christopher Rother von der US-Kanzlei Hausfeld. Das sei die Botschaft an Volkswagen, den Bund und das Land Niedersachsen. In den USA hat VW - im Gegensatz zu Europa - Milliarden ausgegeben, auch um Klagen privater Kunden in einem Vergleich abzurÃ¤umen.

Das passiert nun bei Gericht

Trotz der umfangreichen Klage werde es am Landgericht den gewohnten Ablauf geben, betonte eine Sprecherin in Braunschweig. Die eingegangenen Unterlagen wÃ¼rden nun geprÃ¼ft und einem zustÃ¤ndigen Richter Ã¼bermittelt, der Ã¼ber den weiteren Ablauf entscheide.

"Wir haben seit Anfang des Jahres zwei Spezialkammern eingerichtet, die auf entsprechende Verfahren eingerichtet sind", hieÃŸ es.

Anzeige: Zum 30. November kÃ¶nnt ihr eure Kfz-Versicherung kÃ¼ndigen und eine neue wÃ¤hlen. Die Allianz bietet zu dieser Gelegenheit Neukunden einen einmaligen Willkommens-Rabatt in HÃ¶he von 50 Euro an. â†’ Was eure Kfz-Versicherung kostet, kÃ¶nnt ihr bei der Allianz innerhalb weniger Minuten berechnen â†’ Jetzt kostenlos und unverbindlich direkt bei der Allianz beraten lassen: 0800 7243951 (kostenlos)

Das ist keine echte Sammelklage wie in den USA

Die Strategie, einzelne AnsprÃ¼che privater Kunden zu bÃ¼ndeln, um ihnen so in der Summe mehr Schlagkraft zu verleihen, orientiert sich an den Musterverfahren im Kapitalmarktrecht.

Echte "Sammelklagen" wie etwa in den USA gibt es in Deutschland jedoch nicht. Forderungen, dies auch hier einzufÃ¼hren, tauchten auch im Bundestagswahlkampf auf.

Der Bundesverband der Verbraucherzentrale (vzbv) sieht das Braunschweiger Verfahren grundsÃ¤tzlich positiv. "Vom VW-Skandal betroffene Kunden verdienen eine EntschÃ¤digung und Wiedergutmachung des Schadens. Wenn sie dabei von Anwaltskanzleien unterstÃ¼tzt werden, ist das legitim", meinte vzbv-Chef Klaus MÃ¼ller.

Welche Nachteile es fÃ¼r die VW-KlÃ¤ger geben kÃ¶nnte

Man dÃ¼rfe dabei aber nicht vergessen, dass es auch mÃ¶gliche Nachteile gebe: "Abtretungsmodelle, wie das der Kanzlei Hausfeld, sind nicht der optimale Weg fÃ¼r eine EntschÃ¤digung der betroffenen Verbraucher. Denn sie bieten nur fÃ¼r MassenschadensfÃ¤lle LÃ¶sungen, die fÃ¼r Kanzleien auch eine entsprechende Rendite erwarten lassen. Hohe Provisionen im Falle einer erfolgreichen Klage fÃ¼hren dazu, dass Verbraucher nicht den vollen Umfang ihres Schadens ersetzt bekommen." Daher mÃ¼sse die Musterfeststellungsklage endlich eingefÃ¼hrt werden.

Nach Angaben eines VW-Sprechers wurde bislang in gut 900 zivilrechtlichen FÃ¤llen entschieden - und in 70 bis 75 Prozent dieser FÃ¤lle hÃ¤tten die Richter die Klage abgewiesen. Insgesamt seien gut 7000 zivilrechtliche Verfahren anhÃ¤ngig.

TEXT:
President Jacob Zuma is tired of being blamed for every problem the country faced, EWN reported on Monday.

"Even when someone has lost a shoelace, the problem is Zuma. When there's a drought, they say it's because of Zuma," the president reportedly said during a speech on Sunday.



#Zuma: In S Africa, people say they have problems because of Zuma. Everything is blamed on Zuma. Even if you lose a shoelace, U blame Zuma. â€” Scapegoat (@AndiMakinana) November 5, 2017

Zuma: We (ANC) don't exist in a vacuum. The challenges in the ANC and in the alliance. What is the balance of forces? November 5, 2017



Zuma was speaking at a a lecture on former ANC president Oliver Tambo held in Kagiso on Sunday, but made clear from the beginning that he would not be speaking about Tambo, but politics in general.

Zuma also said that he looked forward to stepping down as president.

"I am very happy that I am leaving my position in December," he said.
TITLE: Zuma: Stop Blaming Me For Everything That Goes Wrong

MALTRAITANCE ANIMALE - Une enquÃªte filmÃ©e en camÃ©ra cachÃ©e rÃ©vÃ¨le les conditions de vie -et surtout de mort- des souris dans un grand laboratoire parisien. RÃ©alisÃ©e par l'association Animal Testing, elle a Ã©tÃ© relayÃ©e par LibÃ©ration ce lundi 6 novembre. L'association s'Ã©tait dÃ©jÃ  fait connaÃ®tre pour avoir rÃ©vÃ©lÃ© des expÃ©riences sur les chiens financÃ©es par le TÃ©lÃ©thon, ainsi que les conditions de vies de singes enfermÃ©s dans le sous-sol d'un hÃ´pital parisien.

Face camÃ©ra, le visage et la voix brouillÃ©s pour garantir son anonymat, une technicienne de laboratoire tÃ©moigne de la duretÃ© de ces conditions de travail face Ã  la souffrance infligÃ©e aux animaux, images Ã  l'appui. La vidÃ©o peut Ãªtre visionnÃ©e sur Youtube, attention, certaines images peuvent heurter la sensibilitÃ©.

"Un chercheur m'a demandÃ© de prÃ©lever du sang sur plusieurs dizaines de souris", raconte-t-elle, "autant de sang qu'il Ã©tait possible sur chaque animal, sans anesthÃ©sie, en les prÃ©levant au niveau de l'Å“il". Pour elle, c'Ã©tait la demande de trop, qui l'a poussÃ©e Ã  contacter l'association. "On ne peut pas prÃ©lever du sang sur un Ãªtre vivant jusqu'Ã  temps qu'il n'y ait plus de sang, comme si c'Ã©tait un flacon, et qu'il meure de ce qu'on lui fait subir."

D'aprÃ¨s cette technicienne, interrogÃ©e par LibÃ©ration, le laboratoire parisien accueille simultanÃ©ment plusieurs milliers de souris, modifiÃ©es gÃ©nÃ©tiquement dans la plupart des cas et rendues malades. Certaines ont des tumeurs tellement grosse qu'un chercheur s'amuse: "c'est comme si elles se baladaient avec un sac Ã  dos".

"Ce n'est pas Ã©vident les dislocations vertÃ©brales"

En thÃ©orie, les animaliers de laboratoires doivent "apporter un bien-Ãªtre aux animaux de laboratoire et assurer la prise en charge technique des expÃ©rimentations", rÃ©sume la fiche Onisep de la profession. La lanceuse d'alerte, elle, s'occupe de changer leurs litiÃ¨res, de les sevrer, de prÃ©lever leur sang, organes, tumeurs, leurs injecter des produits ou des cellules cancÃ©reuses. Et de les tuer.

Une technique courante, indique-t-elle dans la vidÃ©o, est la dislocation verticale, que l'on voit rÃ©alisÃ©e par une autre salariÃ©e. Elle consiste Ã  tirer brusquement sur la queue et la tÃªte de l'animal, et qui ne marche pas toujours du premier coup. "Ã‡a j'en ai fait, je dirais, des centaines de fois", tÃ©moigne la lanceuse d'alerte.

D'autres souris sont intoxiquÃ©es au CO2, d'abord endormies dans un caisson puis mises Ã  mort. Une autre animaliÃ¨re commente: "Quand j'en ai le temps, je fais comme Ã§a, parce que ce n'est pas Ã©vident les dislocations vertÃ©brales". Dans les images filmÃ©es, une souris continue de se dÃ©battre dans ce caisson alors que toutes les autres sont mortes.

Les protocoles scientifiques sont en thÃ©orie sensÃ©s prendre en compte des "points limites" de douleur. Dans la rÃ©alitÃ©, ils ne sont pas toujours respectÃ©s, comme en atteste cette enquÃªte. Certaines souris perdent leurs yeux dans ces expÃ©riences, ou deviennent aveugles. D'autres meurent de leurs souffrances. Certains protocoles prÃ©voient mÃªme de ne pas les anesthÃ©sier, pour ne pas interfÃ©rer avec les rÃ©sultats des expÃ©riences.

La directive europÃ©enne qui encadre ces expÃ©riences Ã©rige normalement trois rÃ¨gles centrales, baptisÃ©es les trois R: la rÃ©duction du nombre d'animaux, le raffinement dans leur prise en charge, et, Ã  terme, leur remplacement.

"Le modÃ¨le des animaux n'est pas forcÃ©ment le bon"

Dans les faits, tÃ©moigne la lanceuse d'alerte, les scientifiques poursuivent les tests sur animaux par habitude. Quand, elle les interrogent Ã  ce sujet, ils lui rÃ©pondent ainsi: "parce que quand j'ai fait des Ã©tudes, on a Ã©tudiÃ© sur des souris, quand on Ã©change avec des confrÃ¨res ou Ã  travers les pays, comme tout le monde a dÃ©jÃ  travaillÃ© avec des souris, on continue Ã  le faire".

Pour les animaliers qui travaillent avec ces animaux, cette situation est d'autant plus dure que le veto dont ils disposent en thÃ©orie sur certaines expÃ©rience est trÃ¨s souvent outrepassÃ©. "Ã‡a nous dÃ©truit", insiste la technicienne. "Il n'y a plus de goÃ»t Ã  la vie." Au bas de la hiÃ©rarchie, leur parole n'est guÃ¨re Ã©coutÃ©e, ajoute-t-elle.

Elle-mÃªme Ã©tait dans un premier favorable Ã  ces tests, qu'elle jugeait comme un moindre mal. Mais en intÃ©grant le comitÃ© d'Ã©thique du laboratoire, elle prend conscience que les souris sont traitÃ©es "comme des objets".

1,9 millions d'animaux ont Ã©tÃ© utilisÃ©s en 2015 dans la recherche, d'aprÃ¨s une enquÃªte du ministÃ¨re de l'enseignement supÃ©rieur, de la recherche, et de l'innovation. Parmi tous ces cobayes, plus d'un million de souris ont Ã©tÃ© employÃ©es.

"On n'est absolument pas contre la recherche", prÃ©cise auprÃ¨s de LibÃ©ration Joanna Trouchaud, responsable de la communication d'Animal Testing. "Mais on estime que le modÃ¨le des animaux n'est pas forcÃ©ment le bon." L'association, qui a lancÃ© une pÃ©tition en ligne, demande "qu'une commission d'enquÃªte parlementaire ait lieu sur l'expÃ©rimentation animale".

C'est inconditionnellement une bonne nouvelle pour les QuÃ©bÃ©cois : nous pouvons nous remettre Ã  rÃªver d'un QuÃ©bec meilleur, d'un projet de sociÃ©tÃ© emballant, plutÃ´t que de simplement voter contre tel parti ou tel projet. Ã€ l'heure oÃ¹ la CAQ tente de se faire du capital politique sur le dos des soi-disant Â« vieux partis Â» et depuis le temps que le PLQ fait campagne contre les Â« mÃ©chants sÃ©paratistes Â», il y a de la place sur la scÃ¨ne politique quÃ©bÃ©coise pour un parti qui mise sur des grands projets de sociÃ©tÃ© pour faire rÃªver les QuÃ©bÃ©cois. Una procedura che rallenta la scrittura, ma attualmente inevitabile.

TEXT:
Inserire la "i" sui messaggi sta diventato un problema per i possessori di un iPhone. A pochi giorni dal lancio mondiale del prodotto celebrativo iPhone X, infatti, i dispositivi Apple stanno registrando qualche problema, cosÃ¬ come molti utenti hanno riportato sui social media. Un bug (errore informatico) che, visto il costo degli ultimi nati in casa Cupertino, ha fatto arrabbiare piÃ¹ di qualche fan del marchio.

La lettera "I" (che, tra l'altro, in inglese equivale al nostro "io") non viene riconosciuta come corretta dal sistema operativo iOS 11, il quale vorrebbe correggere ogni occorrenza della lettera con una "a": un comportamento strano registrato anche gli iPad e che - considerando la "i" iniziale distintiva dei prodotti Apple - sembra proprio uno scherzo del destino.

This "I" autocorrect iOS bug is like a virus taking over everyones iPhone lol â€” Kenny âš¡ï¸ (@imkenny_) 6 novembre 2017

Il bug ha colpito ogni app in cui viene utilizzata la tastiera, tra cui, quindi, anche Instagram, Twitter e Facebook. A ogni modo, niente paura: Ã¨ possibile correggere il malfunzionamento della tastiera, modificando le lettere interne a una parola giÃ  digitata. Una procedura che rallenta la scrittura, ma attualmente inevitabile.

Has anyone figured out how to fix this stupid iPhone bug that changes letters randomly into question marks ? pic.twitter.com/ZVfi804tDb â€” marco nelor (@marconelor) 6 novembre 2017

Il bug ha iniziato a manifestarsi a seguito dell'aggiornamento allo iOS 11.1, il quale ha messo a disposizione una serie di nuovi emoji per i clienti Apple ma che ha portato con sÃ© una serie di fastidiosi bug su tutti i dispositivi messi in vendita da Cupertino. L'azienda ha ammesso il malfunzionamento e ha annunciato che verrÃ  sistemato al piÃ¹ presto.
TITLE: Le tastiere degli iPhone colpite da un bug che non permette di inserire la lettera "i"

SUMMARY:
ADVERTISEMENTThe Collins Dictionary has said the "word of the year" is "fake news" though of course that's two words.
While Trump may have helped Fake News win the word-of-the-year mantle, India has been quite a fake news factory.
BJP leader Priti Gandhi posted Julian Assange's fake endorsement of Narendra Modi for Prime Minister which Wikileaks had to deny.
"Now they want us to bleed more by telling the state government to stop state advertisements as well," he said.
The government's idea to crack down on fake news sounds like good news.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

The Collins Dictionary has said the "word of the year" is "fake news" though of course that's two words. It had seen an unprecedented usage increase of 365% since 2016. "Fake news today is legitimate news," it said.

Helen Newstead, the head of language content, said, "Fake news, either as a statement of fact or as an accusation, has been inescapable, contributing to the undermining of society's trust in news reporting."

While Trump may have helped Fake News win the word-of-the-year mantle, India has been quite a fake news factory.

Now, according to Asian Age, the government is contemplating cracking down on fake news.

And about time. Fake news in India is like air pollution in Delhi â€“ toxic, stubborn and growing stronger.

The government has said official advertisements should be denied to outlets that indulge in "unethical reporting", news published out of "bad intent" and "fake news".

The Directorate of Advertising & Visual Publicity will stop release of advertisements to such publications. Until now the print media policy already stated a newspaper could be suspended from empanelment if it was found to have deliberately submitted false information regarding circulation.

This is not symbolic. Government ads are a major source of revenue for media.

The devil, as always, lies in the details. What is fake news? And who defines it? Who defines bad intent? Clearly one person's fake news is another person's truth or at least their agenda.

Fake news in India is like air pollution in Delhi â€“ toxic, stubborn and growing stronger.

Take a few recent examples:

During the riots in Basirhat, an image of a burning vehicle was sent out as part of a call to #SaveBengal. It was shared by Nupur Sharma, BJP spokesperson from Delhi and used on a flyer for protests. The image, it turned out, was from the 2002 Gujarat riots under Narendra Modi's watch.

BJP IT cell head Amit Malviya has been caught more than once peddling fake news, tweets he has refused to take down even after they have been proved to be false. Once he circulated a mischievously edited video clip of NDTV anchor Ravish Kumar. Another time during the Ram Rahim trial he posted a picture of Rahul Gandhi meeting Sant Niranjan Dass of Dera Sach Khand Ballan but captioned it as "Rahul Gandhi visited Dera Sach Sauda as recently as Jan 2017 to seek support."

BJP leader Priti Gandhi posted Julian Assange's fake endorsement of Narendra Modi for Prime Minister which Wikileaks had to deny.

These could be honest mistakes. Who among us has not fallen for fake news, especially when it fits our ideological bias? But sometimes it's far more deliberate and it comes from within the government itself, not some mischief monger on social media.

The state-run Press Information Bureau infamously photoshopped a picture of Narendra Modi looking at flood-ravaged Chennai with divyadrishti clarity through his chopper window. And of course, that iconic "rare" picture of Modi sweeping the floor at a 1988 RSS rally turned out to be a well-morphed fake photo.

So when it comes to curing the epidemic of fake news, physician heal thyself.

Does this mean the BJP is the sole offender? Of course, not. But as Rohan Venkataramakrishnan points out in Scroll, the BJP was an "early pioneer when it came to using the internet for organizing and building political awareness" and it also "has been at the forefront of the fake news phenomenon, with top party leaders and ministers occasionally revealing the kinds of dishonest messages that are much more rampant among the base."

Even more worryingly, in a country where the phrase "anti-national"can be used casually as a bludgeon to silence any dissent that is too bothersome, these new DAVP guidelines could just be another weapon to bring media to heel. The Centre has already told the Jammu and Kashmir government to stop advertising in local newspapers that allegedly publish "anti-national"articles "glamorizing terrorists and anti-national elements". Shujaat Bukhari, editor of Rising Kashmir told HT that three major newspapers there, including his own, are banned from getting central government ads for eight years because they cover "anti-national" issues, for example, the funerals of militants. "Now they want us to bleed more by telling the state government to stop state advertisements as well," he said.

So when it comes to curing the epidemic of fake news, physician heal thyself.

Government ads have long been part of a strategy to make sure that media does not get too uppity. As other ad revenues shrink government ads gain even more clout.

In 2012, Dhirendra K. Jha dubbed Nitish Kumar Bihar's editor-in-chief because he used the government's ad budget to control and bend the media to his will. The editor of Bihartimes.com said though it has been "No. 1" since inception in 1999, its application for empanelment with the Public Relations Department was kept pending without any "concrete reason" while a site based in Bhopal with tenuous connections to Bihar got government ads. He said he believes it's because his site carries reports related to corruption in the state. An Urdu paper Pindar ran afoul of the government because of a piece by its chief editor that apparently upset the government. The editor, Raihan Ghani, said he was demoted to managing editor and eventually resigned. Curiously the year after Ghani was gagged, the paper's government ad revenues ballooned from 1 lakh to 24 and the year after to 40 lakh.

When the ABP group in Bengal was perceived at loggerheads with the Trinamool government, Mamata Banerjee had banned their newspapers from state libraries. Global campaign group Avaaz said that five West Bengal outdoor advertising agencies and one newspaper group refused to run ads urging Mamata Banerjee to "stop attacking protesters and start attacking the problem" after the gangrape of a young woman in Kamduni. Jayalalithaa's Tamil Nadu was boomtown for lawsuits against media perceived as being overly critical of the government. In five years it filed 213 defamation cases against political opponents, 55 of them against media houses for "derogatory " statements whether it was reporting on the CM's vacations or water scarcity in Tamil Nadu. Its predecessor DMK was a poor second with 40 cases between 2006 and 2011.

The government's idea to crack down on fake news sounds like good news. Who could argue with punishing the purveyors of fake news? But the fear is it will have little to do with promoting free and fair journalism and far more to do with the carrot-and-stick policy that makes media toe the line.

Also On HuffPost:
TITLE: Is The Government's Crackdown On Fake News Another Way Of Controlling The Media?

SUMMARY:
"Violence is really a daily occurrence at the hospital," said Clayborne, who spent much of career working as a forensic psychiatric nurse.
A new survey of almost 2,000 health-care workers being released on Monday by the Ontario Council of Hospital Unions (OCHU) bears out that contention.
And it isn't only front-line staff like nurses and personal support workers who are being subjected to physical and verbal attacks, he said.
"The rate of assault against clerical staff, against cleaners, against dietary aides would be in the neighbourhood of about 34 per cent."
Another factor is that the health-care sector is female-dominant â€” 85 per cent of staff are women â€” and societal attitudes are reflected within hospitals' walls, Hurley suggested.
TEXT:
TORONTO â€” As a 42-year nursing veteran of Ontario's hospital system, Linda Clayborne is no stranger to what's become a growing phenomenon â€” escalating incidents of violence perpetrated by patients and even family members against front-line health-care staff.

"I've been kicked, spat on, bit, pushed and had verbal abuse," said Clayborne, who retired in June 2016 from St. Joseph's Hospital in Hamilton and now works part-time doing private nursing.

"Violence is really a daily occurrence at the hospital," said Clayborne, who spent much of career working as a forensic psychiatric nurse.

Linda Clayborne, a forensic nurse who is now retired after 32 years, is photographed at her home in Hamilton, Ont. on Saturday.

But she said it's a scenario played out in hospitals across the province and throughout Canada, with nurses, personal support workers and other staff bearing the brunt of patients' emotional meltdowns.

A new survey of almost 2,000 health-care workers being released on Monday by the Ontario Council of Hospital Unions (OCHU) bears out that contention.

Almost 70 per cent of respondents reported experiencing at least one incident of physical violence in the past year, while 20 per cent said they had been subjected to such assaults nine or more times during that period.

Eighty-three per cent said they had endured at least one incident of non-physical abuse, such as name-calling, threatening gestures or intimidation, with 35 per cent reporting at least nine such occurrences in the last year.

42 per cent sexually harassed, assaulted

Sexual harassment or assault also occurred, with 42 per cent of workers reporting at least one incident, and six per cent saying it happened nine times or more.

OCHU president Michael Hurley called the findings "staggering."

And it isn't only front-line staff like nurses and personal support workers who are being subjected to physical and verbal attacks, he said. "The rate of assault against clerical staff, against cleaners, against dietary aides would be in the neighbourhood of about 34 per cent."

Hurley said violence by patients and family members can occur in virtually any part of a hospital, from the emergency department to the intensive care unit to obstetrics.

"They may be people with mental illness, people high on opiates, people distressed about the quality of their care, or distressed about the length of time they've waited â€” and they take that aggression out on the health-care staff that they meet."

Had she had a Plexiglas barrier completely around her, that (assault) couldn't have happened. Micheal Hurley, OCHU president

He cited the recent case of a mentally ill man who had come to a Smiths Falls, Ont., hospital and grabbed a pair of blunt scissors off the admitting clerk's desk and "plunged them" into her neck.

"Had she had a Plexiglas barrier completely around her, that couldn't have happened," said Hurley, adding that budget restraints often mean hospitals aren't making even such minimal investments to protect staff.

Another factor is that the health-care sector is female-dominant â€” 85 per cent of staff are women â€” and societal attitudes are reflected within hospitals' walls, Hurley suggested.

"You've got in Canadian society, unfortunately, a very high degree of tolerance for violence against women," he said.

"So you've got this general societal attitude and it doesn't stop at the door of the hospital. It comes right in and it's compounded by the fact that if you assault someone in a hospital, you may not face charges."

Ambulances drive through the emergency department at St. Michael's Hospital in Toronto on Oct. 20 2016.

Clayborne said violent incidents began rising about 15 years ago, in lockstep with ongoing staff cuts that left front-line workers to deal with unruly patients, where once trained crisis teams were there to respond.

"In my opinion as a nurse, I am there to nurse, to nurture, to help people get well," she said. "It's become an expectation that I become part of the goon squad, so to speak."

"For me and my colleagues, we don't want to do that. We've been hurt, we've been thrown to the floor. I had my head banged against the wall."

Clayborne said she was traumatized by one incident in particular: a Code White â€” an SOS when a worker is in trouble â€” was called during one shift and she and other staff went racing to help a nurse who was being attacked by a male patient.

We've been hurt, we've been thrown to the floor. I had my head banged against the wall. Linda Clayborne

"She was on the floor in the fetal position ... and all I could hear was the thump of his foot against her back," she said.

In another incident, a worker was struck by a food tray and thrown to the ground, hitting her head on a cement floor. She suffered permanent brain damage.

Scott Sharp is also trying to recover from what may be permanent injury from an attack.

The personal support worker was on the midnight shift in the emergency department at a Guelph, Ont., hospital in January 2015 when he ran to help co-workers restrain a physically aggressive young man who was high on crystal meth.

"He punched me in the face, like uppercut me," recalled Sharp, 48, who lives in nearby Elora.

Sharp lost his balance and slid under the gurney. His back then hit the floor and his head slammed through a steel rack and into a wall.

Devastation for some health workers

The father of four ended up with spinal damage that has left him reliant on a walker or crutches, suffering chronic pain and bladder-control problems.

Sharp said he has had difficulty getting compensation from the Workplace Safety and Insurance Board (WSIB), which refused to pay for some of his medications.

And when his wife had to take time off work to be his caregiver for many months, she didn't get paid, devastating the family financially.

I shouldn't, but I think back that if I hadn't have let my guard down, I'd still be the dad I was before and I'd still be the husband I was before. Scott Sharp, who suffered spinal damage after incident

"We ended up losing our house," said Sharp, his voice breaking.

"I shouldn't, but I think back that if I hadn't have let my guard down, I'd still be the dad I was before and I'd still be the husband I was before."

While he had lots of support from co-workers, that wasn't the case with hospital administrators, said Sharp, who wants to see more accountability from upper management in cases of workplace violence.

But under legislation, hospitals can't be sued for work-related injuries. Police and public prosecutors typically discourage workers from seeking charges against patients, especially those with dementia, mental illness or under the influence of drugs, because conviction is unlikely, Hurley of OCHU said.

Union: More gov't protection, accountability

"It's not that we want people to be prosecuted ... but from our perspective it should be the courts that make that determination whether a person at the time of the attack (understood) the nature of what they were doing or not."

OCHU also wants hospitals to beef up protection for staff and it is calling on the Ontario government to provide enhanced legal protection for people who report violent incidents to their superiors _ something both Hurley and Clayborne said most workers are reluctant to do because they fear reprisals.

"I think that the hospital has to have some responsibility to keep us safe," said Clayborne, including "going to the government and saying: 'Our employees are being beaten and we need the money to keep them safe.'

"But it's not happening."

Also On HuffPost:
TITLE: Ontario Union Demands More Protection Against Rising Violence Toward Hospital Staff

SUMMARY:
CANBERRA -- One Nation leader Pauline Hanson has launched her Queensland election campaign on Monday with a champagne start to her party's "Battler Bus" tour of the state's regions.
She is launching a 'battler bus' with champagne.
The Battler Bus also includes a hashtag for people to follow on social media, #PeopleB4Politics.
'The3million' campaign wants EU nationals to maintain their current rights under a withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union.
#PeopleB4Politics https://t.co/yWH665av9j â€” the3million (@The3Million) November 4, 2017#EUcitizens are your neighbours, colleagues, family members, friends.
TEXT:
Pauline Hanson: "I think it's time for One Nation and honestly I think this is going to be bigger than what it was in 1998."

CANBERRA -- One Nation leader Pauline Hanson has launched her Queensland election campaign on Monday with a champagne start to her party's "Battler Bus" tour of the state's regions.

While a smash of bubbly is a common choice for christening a vessel, the use of champagne fizz in this instance has caught the eye of a few political opponents as being not exactly "battlerish".

She is launching a 'battler bus' with champagne. YOU CAN'T MAKE THIS UP. pic.twitter.com/gO2gSOFZKj â€” Sam Dastyari (@samdastyari) November 6, 2017

The launch of the white and blue bus bearing Hanson's face constitutes a late joining of the Queensland election trail for the senator as she was caught out of the country on a parliamentary trip to India when the Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk called the election.

Hanson confirmed a preference deal with the Katter's Australian Party ahead of Labor and the LNP but would not confirm whether the two parties would vote together as a block in the next state parliament.

"I think it's time for One Nation and honestly I think this is going to be bigger than what it was in 1998," she told reporters in Brisbane before the bus took off.

The Battler Bus also includes a hashtag for people to follow on social media, #PeopleB4Politics.

A quick search of the hashtag did not find a flood of One Nation mentions; rather it has been used in United Kingdom in a campaign to protect the rights of millions of European citizens who live in the UK but will be affected by Brexit.

'The3million' campaign wants EU nationals to maintain their current rights under a withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union.

In particular they want EU nationals to keep the right to bring family members to the UK, including from outside the EU, as now.

The residency #citizensrights of 4.5 million people need to be sorted before talks can move on to the future relationship. #PeopleB4Politics https://t.co/yWH665av9j â€” the3million (@The3Million) November 4, 2017

#EUcitizens are your neighbours, colleagues, family members, friends. Please support us to put #PeopleB4Politics . #citizensrights â€” Anke in Brexitland (@solsikke66) November 4, 2017

No-one owns hashtags and the One Nation "Battler Bus" juggernaut may soon soon take over its use but the anti-immigration populist party is starting the week with a few contradictions.
TITLE: Pauline Hanson Adopts Pro-Immigration Hashtag #peopleb4politics For Queensland Election

PARADISE PAPERS - Dix-huit mois aprÃ¨s l'enquÃªte sur les Panama Papers, le Consortium international des journalistes d'investigation, en partenariat avec plusieurs mÃ©dias franÃ§ais comme Le Monde et Franceinfo, rÃ©cidive avec les "Paradise Papers". Et cette fois, ce sont les noms de proches de Justin Trudeau, Donald Trump mais aussi Elizabeth II qui ressortent dans la premiÃ¨re sÃ©rie de rÃ©vÃ©lations.

Les "Paradise Papers" sont le fruit d'une fuite de donnÃ©es du cabinet de conseil britannique Appleby, spÃ©cialisÃ©s dans les montages off-shores. Toutefois, Ã  la diffÃ©rence des Panama Papers qui mettaient en lumiÃ¨re un systÃ¨me illÃ©gal, les premiers Paradise Papers dÃ©voilÃ©s ce dimanche 5 novembre parlent de montages sophistiquÃ©s mais lÃ©gaux qui relÃ¨vent plus de l'optimisation fiscale que de la fraude, mais qui interrogent davantage sur la moralitÃ© des personnalitÃ©s concernÃ©es.

Wilbur Ross, secrÃ©taire d'Ã©tat au commerce amÃ©ricain

Parmi les premiers noms Ã  faire surface ce dimanche 5 novembre, se trouve celui de Wilbur Ross, actuel secrÃ©taire amÃ©ricain du commerce de Donald Trump. Autre information susceptible de provoquer un nouveau tollÃ© dans l'administration: les liens de l'entreprise de Wilbur Ross avec l'une des plus grosses sociÃ©tÃ©s russes de gaz et de pÃ©trole, "Sibur", dirigÃ©e par des proches de Vladimir Poutine. Comme le prÃ©cise Le Monde, Sibur est actuellement la propriÃ©tÃ© d'un des gendres du prÃ©sident russe, Kirill Chamalov, et de Guennadi Timtchenko, qui a dÃ©jÃ  fait les frais des sanctions Ã©conomiques amÃ©ricaines aprÃ¨s l'invasion de la CrimÃ©e.

Stephen Bronfman, "le gars de la finance" de Trudeau

Stephen Bronfman est l'un des soutiens de la premiÃ¨re heure de Justin Trudeau, dont il est l'ancien trÃ©sorier de campagne. Une campagne que le premier ministre canadien a remportÃ© notamment grÃ¢ce Ã  ses positions contre l'Ã©vasion fiscale. Mais selon les informations rÃ©vÃ©lÃ©es par les Paradise Papers, Stephen Bronfman et sa sociÃ©tÃ© Claridge auraient investi dans une structure financiÃ¨re opaque des Ã®les CaÃ®man -un "trust" baptisÃ© le Kolber Trust. L'objectif Ã©tant bien sÃ»r d'Ã©chapper Ã  certaines taxes.

Comme le rappelle Le Monde, possÃ©der un "trust" au Canada n'est pas illÃ©gal, Ã  condition de respecter certaines rÃ¨gles: ainsi l'entreprise n'est exemptÃ©e de taxe que si les dÃ©cisions la concernant sont prises hors du territoire canadien. Ce qui, selon les rÃ©vÃ©lations des Paradise Papers, n'a pas Ã©tÃ© le cas pour le trust Kolbert.

Elizabeth II, le duchÃ© de Lancastre et Brighthouse

Dans la longue liste du patrimoine royal britannique, figure le "DuchÃ© de Lancaster", une sociÃ©tÃ© chargÃ©e de gÃ©rer les biens de la reine. Selon les rÃ©vÃ©lations des Paradise Paper, ce duchÃ© a investi 7,5 millions de dollars dans un fonds situÃ© aux Ã®les CaÃ¯man, qui aurait par la suite investi dans une chaÃ®ne britannique d'Ã©lectromÃ©nager "Brighthouse".

Or cette chaÃ®ne a dÃ©jÃ  provoquÃ© la polÃ©mique au Royaume-Uni pour ses mÃ©thodes de ventes agressives et des surfacturations de clients, mais aussi pour avoir rÃ©duit de faÃ§on drastique le montant de ses impÃ´ts, grÃ¢ce Ã  un prÃªt accordÃ© Ã  une sociÃ©tÃ© luxembourgeoise, comme le souligne Le Monde.

Sie wollen nicht mehr in die Schule gehen, kÃ¶nnen nachts nicht schlafen, fÃ¼hlen sich traurig und bedrÃ¼ckt: Schon die Kleinsten in unserer Gesellschaft leiden unter psychischem Stress und hohem Erwartungsdruck, warnen Psychologen.

Kaum jemand im deutschsprachigen Raum hat sich mit dem Thema Kindererziehung wohl so lange und lebensnah beschÃ¤ftigt wie der Schweizer Kinderarzt Remo Largo.

Auch wenn sein erstes Buch â€œBabyjahreâ€ schon fast zwei Jahrzehnte alt ist, gehÃ¶rt es noch immer zur Grundausstattung junger Eltern.

Viele Eltern wollen ihr Kind maximal fÃ¶rdern - auch Ã¼ber sein Potenzial hinaus

Seit mehr als 30 Jahren befasst sich der â€œbekannteste Kinderarzt der Schweizâ€ mit der kindlichen Entwicklung und dem Einfluss, den unsere Gesellschaft darauf hat.

Largo, der selbst Vater von drei TÃ¶chtern und auch lange schon GroÃŸvater ist, beobachtet ein entscheidendes Problem in der modernen Erziehung: Er ist der Ansicht, dass viele Eltern eine falsche Vorstellung davon haben, wie ihr Kind zu einem glÃ¼cklichen, erfolgreichen Menschen heranwÃ¤chst.

â€œEin Kind ist darauf ausgelegt, sein Begabungspotenzial auszuschÃ¶pfenâ€, sagte er der HuffPost. â€œDoch in unserer Gesellschaft ist das fÃ¼r viele unglaublich schwer geworden.â€

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Ein Hirnforscher erklÃ¤rt, was Kinder mehr als alles andere von ihren Eltern brauchen

Schuld sei ein Irrglaube, dem viele Eltern unterliegen. â€œViele Eltern versuchen, ihr Kind Ã¼ber sein Begabungspotenzial hinaus zu fÃ¶rdernâ€, erklÃ¤rt er. â€œDas ist aber nicht mÃ¶glich.â€

Die Folge: â€œSie Ã¼berfordern das Kind und verunsichern es.â€

Largo zieht einen simplen Vergleich: â€œJedes Kind ist verschieden groÃŸ. Wenn ein Kind zu wenig Nahrung bekommt, wird es kleiner. Wird es Ã¼berfÃ¼ttert, wird es nicht grÃ¶ÃŸer, sondern nur dick. So ist es auch mit den geistigen FÃ¤higkeiten.â€

So wie das kÃ¶rperliche Wachstum eines Kindes also limitiert ist, stÃ¶ÃŸt es auch bei seinen Begabungen und StÃ¤rken an klare Grenzen.

(Das hat Largo Ã¼brigens zu Kindern zu sagen, die nicht gehorchen; der Text geht nach dem Video weiter:)

Ein Kinderarzt erklÃ¤rt: Das ist der oft Ã¼bersehene Grund, warum Kinder ihren Eltern nicht gehorchen





Eltern mÃ¼ssten erkennen und akzeptieren, dass ihr Kind in manchen Feldern besser sei als in anderen und dass es nichts bringe, die nicht so stark ausgeprÃ¤gten FÃ¤higkeiten ohne RÃ¼cksicht auf seine eigentlichen BedÃ¼rfnisse verbessern zu wollen, erklÃ¤rt Largo.

Dass Eltern ihre Kinder Ã¼ber ihr Potenzial hinaus versuchen zu fÃ¶rdern, lÃ¤sst sich laut Largo durch den gesellschaftlichen Druck erklÃ¤ren.

Zu viel FÃ¶rderung fÃ¼hrt nicht zu mehr Erfolg

Andere Eltern und Erzieher in der Kita setzten MaÃŸstÃ¤be, wie weit ein Kind in einem bestimmten Alter in seiner Entwicklung sein mÃ¼sse. Und in der Schule gehe es weiter - mit starren LehrplÃ¤nen und oft unflexiblen Lehrern.

â€œWenn das eigene Kind dann beispielsweise weniger gut lesen und rechnen kann, als es nach dieser Vorstellung sollte, lÃ¶st das bei den meisten Eltern Ã„ngste aus.â€

Die Reaktion vieler Eltern: stÃ¤rkere FÃ¶rderung - auch dort, wo das Potenzial des Kindes bereits voll ausgeschÃ¶pft ist. Damit entstehe die Gefahr der Ãœberlastung, warnt Largo.

â€œEltern dÃ¼rfen ihre Kinder nicht Ã¼berfordernâ€, sagt er. â€œDie zunehmende Zahl der Burnout-FÃ¤lle selbst bei Kindern zeigt aber, dass viele Eltern genau das tun. Die Kinder wollen dann nicht mehr lernen, kÃ¶nnen nicht mehr schlafen, fÃ¼hlen sich niedergeschlagen.â€

Largos Rat: â€œBemerken Eltern, dass sie ihr Kind Ã¼berfordern, sollten sie sich selbst hinterfragen und sich ehrlich Ã¼berlegen, weshalb sie solchen Druck machen.â€

Viele Eltern machen sich selbst groÃŸen Druck

Die Ursache fÃ¼r ein solches Verhalten der Eltern, so Largos Erfahrung, sei nÃ¤mlich in vielen FÃ¤llen gleich.

â€œDer Grund ist hÃ¤ufig die eigene existenzielle Verunsicherung der Elternâ€, sagt er.
