SUMMARY:
No hay ningÃºn motivo para pensar que la implementaciÃ³n de los principios rectores y el desarrollo de un tratado de este tipo no sean procesos complementarios.
Como era de esperarse, las agrupaciones empresariales insistieron en que no son sujetos obligados frente a los derechos humanos, sino que son sÃ³lo los Estados quienes deben garantizar su respeto.
Por ello, confian en que el mandato del Grupo de Trabajo se mantendrÃ¡ como estÃ¡ y que Ecuador seguirÃ¡ acompaÃ±ando el proceso hasta llevarlo a buen puerto.
Confian, ademÃ¡s, en que los Estados participantes seguirÃ¡n sumÃ¡ndose para aportar de forma proactiva a este proceso.
Lo que llevÃ³ a todas y todos quienes estuvieron en Ginebra fue el consenso de que las empresas transnacionales tienen la obligaciÃ³n de respetar los derechos humanos, y que estas no pueden, ni deben, ser mÃ¡s fuertes que los Estados donde operan.
TEXT:
Por: Eugenia LÃ³pez y Fernanda Hoppenhaym de la organizaciÃ³n civil PODER.*

A mediados de los aÃ±os sesenta, una petrolera perforÃ³ grandes pozas en la selva amazÃ³nica de Ecuador donde arrojÃ³ petrÃ³leo de prueba y residuos tÃ³xicos, sin importar que esa prÃ¡ctica fuera daÃ±ina. Pasaron 26 aÃ±os y la empresa se retirÃ³ dejando un ecosistema devastado y cerca de mil "piscinas" que, cuatro dÃ©cadas despuÃ©s, siguen filtrando sustancias tÃ³xicas y contaminando las aguas subterrÃ¡neas. Aunque ha habido diversos juicios contra la empresa, la contaminaciÃ³n provocada por Texaco-Chevron permanece impune a la fecha.

En MÃ©xico, hace tres aÃ±os, la minera Buenavista del Cobre, filial de Grupo MÃ©xico, contaminÃ³ los rÃ­os Sonora y BacÃ¡nuchi con mÃ¡s de 40 mil metros cÃºbicos de Ã¡cido de sulfato de cobre, afectando de forma directa a 22 mil personas que viven en los siete municipios situados a orillas del rÃ­o Sonora, daÃ±ando su salud y mermando la productividad de la regiÃ³n. A pesar de los exhortos de Naciones Unidas para que el gobierno mexicano atienda este caso, hasta hoy las autoridades no han castigado a ningÃºn responsable del peor desastre ambiental de la minerÃ­a en el paÃ­s.

Situaciones como estas, donde las empresas siguen operando sin problemas, a pesar de haber violentado los derechos de miles o millones de personas, podrÃ­an evitarse en el futuro con la existencia de un tratado internacional que las obligue a responder por sus actos.

Esta iniciativa de Tratado Vinculante, ha sido impulsada a nivel mundial por cientos de agrupaciones civiles que llevan mÃ¡s de una dÃ©cada organizÃ¡ndose para llegar a este momento. MÃ¡s de 200 se hicieron presentes en Ginebra del 23 al 27 de octubre, a fin de impulsar este instrumento diseÃ±ado especialmente para frenar los abusos de las grandes corporaciones.

Fue una semana histÃ³rica en muchos sentidos, pero sobre todo porque marcÃ³ el inicio de la creaciÃ³n de un documento que, de concretarse, proveerÃ¡ los mecanismos jurÃ­dicos necesarios para que las grandes empresas trasnacionales estÃ©n obligadas a respetar los derechos humanos y, en consecuencia, quienes han visto violados sus derechos por parte de esas empresas puedan acceder a la justicia y a la remediaciÃ³n.

Y precisamente el acceso a la justicia y a remediar el daÃ±o constituyen el centro del debate entre grupos empresariales, representantes de los Estados y asociaciones civiles, pues las empresas argumentan que no se requiere un Tratado Vinculante, sino que basta con cumplir con regulaciones voluntarias como los Principios Rectores sobre las Empresas y los Derechos Humanos que Naciones Unidas aprobÃ³ en 2011.

No obstante, como ha seÃ±alado Surya Deva, integrante del Grupo de Trabajo de Naciones Unidas sobre Empresas y Derechos Humanos, sin un Tratado Vinculante nunca podremos garantizar el acceso al remedio, porque las violaciones a derechos humanos por parte de las empresas suceden cada vez mÃ¡s en otros paÃ­ses, y si no contamos con una cadena de jurisdicciÃ³n y de responsabilidad de los Estados a nivel transnacional, las empresas siempre podrÃ¡n evadir la justicia. No hay ningÃºn motivo para pensar que la implementaciÃ³n de los principios rectores y el desarrollo de un tratado de este tipo no sean procesos complementarios.

La discusiÃ³n estuvo a cargo del Grupo de Trabajo Intergubernamental de ComposiciÃ³n Abierta, especialmente generado para desarrollar el Tratado Vinculante sobre derechos humanos, empresas transnacionales y otras empresas (GTI), liderado por Ecuador con apoyo de SudÃ¡frica. En las sesiones participaron los estados miembro de la ONU (MÃ©xico incluido), asÃ­ como agrupaciones empresariales como la International Chamber of Commerce (ICC), la International Organisation of Employees (IOE) y, por supuesto, numerosas organizaciones de la sociedad civil.

A pesar de que las negociaciones iniciaron con crÃ­ticas a la propuesta hecha por Ecuador (principalmente por la falta de tiempo para consultar al interior de los gobiernos y porque el documento necesita trabajar mejor el sustento jurÃ­dico), lo cierto es que al final de la semana se logrÃ³ un acuerdo sobre los principales temas que deberÃ­a abordar un tratado de esta naturaleza, y los Estados participantes lograron involucrarse en un debate tÃ©cnico sobre el contenido para generar este instrumento.

Al tÃ©rmino de las discusiones, el pleno acordÃ³ que Ecuador deberÃ¡ definir en breve una hoja de ruta para llegar con un borrador enriquecido para la siguiente sesiÃ³n del Grupo de Trabajo que se darÃ¡ en 2018.

Como era de esperarse, las agrupaciones empresariales insistieron en que no son sujetos obligados frente a los derechos humanos, sino que son sÃ³lo los Estados quienes deben garantizar su respeto. No obstante, la responsabilidad corporativa frente a los derechos humanos no aumenta ni disminuye si el Estado cumple o no su deber de proteger los derechos humanos, como bien ha seÃ±alado John Ruggie, creador de los Principios Rectores de Empresas y Derechos Humanos.

En este punto cabe seÃ±alar que, aunque el Tratado Vinculante busca frenar los abusos de las grandes empresas, tambiÃ©n permite atacar la captura corporativa del Estado, la cual sucede cuando una Ã©lite econÃ³mica se apropia de la polÃ­tica y la economÃ­a nacional para beneficio propio y, como resultado, el estado de derecho falla al obligar a las empresas a rendir cuentas.

Las organizaciones civiles que participaron en la creaciÃ³n de este tratado, entre ellas PODER, ven con optimismo los avances logrados y se mantienen alerta sobre las posibles amenazas contra un instrumento de este tipo. SeÃ±alan, por ejemplo la intenciÃ³n de algunos paÃ­ses de la UniÃ³n Europea, de cuestionar el mandato de Ecuador dentro del Consejo de Derechos Humanos de la ONU en marzo de 2018 para que no se llegue a discutir un nuevo borrador del documento.

Para algunos Estados y la sociedad civil que participa en este proceso, no hay duda de que el mandato del Grupo Intergubernamental de Trabajo ha sido claro desde el inicio de este proceso, y es un mandato que sigue abierto hasta que se genere el Tratado Vinculante. Por ello, confian en que el mandato del Grupo de Trabajo se mantendrÃ¡ como estÃ¡ y que Ecuador seguirÃ¡ acompaÃ±ando el proceso hasta llevarlo a buen puerto. Confian, ademÃ¡s, en que los Estados participantes seguirÃ¡n sumÃ¡ndose para aportar de forma proactiva a este proceso.

Lo que llevÃ³ a todas y todos quienes estuvieron en Ginebra fue el consenso de que las empresas transnacionales tienen la obligaciÃ³n de respetar los derechos humanos, y que estas no pueden, ni deben, ser mÃ¡s fuertes que los Estados donde operan.

* Fernanda Hopenhaym es directora ejecutiva adjunta de Proyecto sobre OrganizaciÃ³n, Desarrollo, EducaciÃ³n e InvestigaciÃ³n (PODER), y Eugenia LÃ³pez es directora de vinculaciÃ³n de esta misma organizaciÃ³n.
TITLE: El tratado internacional que podrÃ­a poner fin a los abusos de las empresas transnacionales

SUMMARY:
If you think we have to rely on energy from oil, gas and coal because green energy is too expensive, think again.
One former fossil-based energy company is poised to deliver power to the UK from an offshore wind farm that is not only cleaner, but is actually cheaper than energy produced from fossil deposits.
The old arguments for fossil-fuel power are being blown away by Ã˜rsted, a Danish energy company that has made the switch from black to green energy and firmly believes the rest of us need to follow suit.
â€œTransforming the worldâ€™s energy supply from coal, oil and gas to renewables is simply the right thing to do.â€ We asked Matthew about Ã˜rstedâ€™s conversion to a green energy company.
â€œOffshore wind technology is evolving rapidly and the capacity of an offshore turbine has more than doubled over the last decade.
TEXT:
If you think we have to rely on energy from oil, gas and coal because green energy is too expensive, think again. One former fossil-based energy company is poised to deliver power to the UK from an offshore wind farm that is not only cleaner, but is actually cheaper than energy produced from fossil deposits. The old arguments for fossil-fuel power are being blown away by Ã˜rsted, a Danish energy company that has made the switch from black to green energy and firmly believes the rest of us need to follow suit. From 2022, they will offer the lowest ever price for offshore wind in the UK, so we can have our cake and eat it, without hurting the planet while baking it.

â€œClimate change is a very real threat and we must all take responsibility,â€ Matthew Wright, managing director, told us. â€œTransforming the worldâ€™s energy supply from coal, oil and gas to renewables is simply the right thing to do.â€ We asked Matthew about Ã˜rstedâ€™s conversion to a green energy company. How did they manage the breakthrough of making sustainable energy cheaper than fossil fuel? â€œOffshore wind technology is evolving rapidly and the capacity of an offshore turbine has more than doubled over the last decade. Increased wind farm scale, greater efficiencies and a solid supply chain have been key elements of the success story to date, but we cannot overlook the role of successive UK governments in providing the certainty needed for continued investment in offshore wind, enabling it to become the thriving industry it is today.â€ When you think that the first wind farm was only built in 1991, you realise how young the sustainable energy industry is. It is only going to get more and more efficient. But it canâ€™t have been easy transforming a conventional fossil energy-based company into a renewable energy pioneer. â€œItâ€™s quite an achievement when you consider that just five years ago, offshore wind was still a young and relatively small-scale technology with high costs when compared to fossil fuels. We made a bold decision to divest our upstream oil and gas business, and to stop all use of coal. Weâ€™ve ramped up our green investments and have become the worldâ€™s largest developer of offshore wind. â€œOne of the biggest, and arguably most important tasks came in 2012, when the UK government set the industry a challenge to reduce the cost of offshore wind. The industry rose to the challenge and smashed the target three years ahead of schedule. Our Hornsea Project Two wind farm was recently awarded a contract at the lowest ever price for offshore in the UK. This is an incredible achievement not just for us as a company but for the whole industry, making offshore wind cheaper than newly built coal or gas fired power plants,â€ Matthew reveals.

Ã˜rsted
TITLE: Energy Company Calls For Whole World To Go Green

NEW BRAUNFELS, Texas â€• The man police blamed for Sundayâ€™s mass shooting at a Texas church had a â€œconnectionâ€ to the location and was â€œa powder keg waiting to go off,â€ Gov.
He previously lived in Colorado Springs, Colorado, according to public records.
The Air Force said late Sunday that Kelley was court-martialed in 2012 for assault on his spouse and their child.
That same year he was reportedly sued for divorce in New Mexico, The New York Times reported.
Kelley was charged with cruelty to animals in August 2014 while living in an RV park in Colorado Springs, reported The New York Times.
TEXT:
NEW BRAUNFELS, Texas â€• The man police blamed for Sundayâ€™s mass shooting at a Texas church had a â€œconnectionâ€ to the location and was â€œa powder keg waiting to go off,â€ Gov. Greg Abbott said Monday. Devin Patrick Kelley, 26, the suspect in the massacre at First Baptist Church in Sutherland Springs that killed at least 26 and wounded 20, had in-laws who occasionally attended services at the church, but werenâ€™t there on Sunday, Wilson County Sheriff Joe Tackitt told reporters. â€œI do believe that there was a connection between him and this location that will come to light over the coming days,â€ Abbott (R) said during an appearance on â€œCBS This Morningâ€ on Monday. â€œI donâ€™t think this church was picked out at random. I think there was purpose and intent that Devin Kelley had in showing up at this location.â€

Kelley, wearing a bulletproof vest and black tactical gear, opened fire on churchgoers using an â€œassault-type rifleâ€ around 11:30 a.m. during Sunday prayer service, according to law enforcement officials. The suspected gunman most recently lived in New Braunfels, roughly 30 miles northeast of San Antonio, reported the Texas Department of Public Safety. He previously lived in Colorado Springs, Colorado, according to public records. Kelley is a former member of the U.S. Air Force who served in logistics readiness at Holloman Air Force Base in New Mexico from 2010 until his discharge in 2014, according to USAF spokeswoman Ann Stefanek. The Air Force said late Sunday that Kelley was court-martialed in 2012 for assault on his spouse and their child. He received a bad conduct discharge, a 12-month sentence in a military prison and a reduction in rank for the offense. That same year he was reportedly sued for divorce in New Mexico, The New York Times reported. Kelley was charged with cruelty to animals in August 2014 while living in an RV park in Colorado Springs, reported The New York Times. A former neighbor told the Times that someone called the police to report that Kelley struck his pit bull puppy in the head. The case was later dismissed. Abbott on Monday called Kelley â€œa powder keg waiting to go offâ€ and said state law should have prevented him from buying a gun.

â€œIt looks like there was connectionâ€¦ the bottom line is this was not a random act of shooting.â€ -- Texas @GovAbbott pic.twitter.com/G4aOqVMJVw â€” CBS This Morning (@CBSThisMorning) November 6, 2017
TITLE: Mass Shooting Suspect Devin Patrick Kelley Had 'Connection' To Texas Church

SUMMARY:
Valerie Plante speaks to supporters after being elected mayor of Montreal during the municipal election on Sunday.
MONTREAL - ValÃ©rie Plante scored a stunning upset in Montreal's mayoral election on Sunday, defeating incumbent Denis Coderre to become the first woman to win the post.
ValÃ©rie Plante with husband Pierre-Antoine Harvey, right, and their two sons after Plante was elected mayor of Montreal on Sunday.
Plante will be the first female mayor elected in Montreal in the city's 375-year history, and Montreal will be the largest North American city with a female mayor, according to CTV News.
Outgoing Montreal Mayor Denis Coderre makes his concession speech after losing the municipal election on Sunday in Montreal.
TEXT:
Valerie Plante speaks to supporters after being elected mayor of Montreal during the municipal election on Sunday.

MONTREAL - ValÃ©rie Plante scored a stunning upset in Montreal's mayoral election on Sunday, defeating incumbent Denis Coderre to become the first woman to win the post.

Coderre said just after 10:30 p.m. that he'd called Plante to congratulate her. He later announced he was leaving municipal politics.

In her victory speech, Plante reiterated her campaign promises, which include improving public transit and lessening road congestion, as well as adding green spaces and social housing.

ValÃ©rie Plante with husband Pierre-Antoine Harvey, right, and their two sons after Plante was elected mayor of Montreal on Sunday.

"During the course of this campaign, I had one goal in mind: I wanted to put Montrealers first and I'm not going to change that," she told a roomful of cheering supporters at a downtown theatre.

"I'm going to put Montrealers first, I'm going to get Montreal moving again, I'm going to build safer roads for pedestrians, seniors and cyclists."

Plante, 43, was leading with over 51 per cent of the vote with almost all polls reporting, compared to just under 46 per cent for Coderre.

"We have made history," she tweeted. "Thank you, Montreal!"

Plante will be the first female mayor elected in Montreal in the city's 375-year history, and Montreal will be the largest North American city with a female mayor, according to CTV News.

She entered municipal politics in 2013 when she won a council seat in a contest that pitted her against former provincial cabinet minister Louise Harel.

In 2016, she was elected leader of the left-leaning party Projet Montreal.

Plante began the mayoral race as a relative unknown but opinion polls showed her steadily gaining on Coderre as the campaign continued.

ValÃ©rie Plante's supporters react as votes comes in projecting her win on election night during the municipal election in Montreal on Sunday.

The mother of two, who cycles or takes public transit to work, sought throughout the campaign to present herself as less flamboyant and more in touch with Montrealers than her opponent.

Her signature campaign promise was a new 29-stop subway line that would link the city's densely populated northeast to downtown.

During her victory speech, she appealed to the provincial and federal governments to partner with her on her two biggest campaign promises: the subway line and increasing social housing in the city.

"In Quebec and Ottawa, I invite you to act on the strong message that Montrealers are sending you," she said.

"I know we can't do it tomorrow, but we can start working together, immediately, for those who need it most."

Prime Minister Justin Trudeau saluted Plante's historic victory in a tweet late Sunday night.

Congratulations @Val_Plante, first-ever woman elected mayor of Montreal! I'm looking forward to working together on our shared priorities. â€” Justin Trudeau (@JustinTrudeau) November 6, 2017

"Congratulations @Val_Plante, first-ever woman elected mayor of Montreal! I'm looking forward to working together on our shared priorities," he wrote.

The outgoing Coderre, a former Liberal MP and cabinet minister who was elected mayor in 2013, had campaigned largely on his record.

He had highlighted his ambitious infrastructure renewal plan, naming an inspector general to oversee the awarding of city contracts, and negotiating increased powers for the city from the province.

But while Montreal's economy has boomed during his mandate, Coderre was often branded by opponents as an arrogant leader who makes hasty decisions with little consultation.

He was criticized for spending millions on showy projects to celebrate the city's 375th birthday, and drew the ire of dog lovers when he introduced legislation last year to ban pit bulls from the city.

Outgoing Montreal Mayor Denis Coderre makes his concession speech after losing the municipal election on Sunday in Montreal.

In his concession speech, Coderre announced he would be leaving municipal politics but said he remained proud of what he'd accomplished.

"I'm leaving with my head high," he said. "Montreal is an exceptional city, Montreal is a metropolis that is the envy of the world."

Incumbents fared better elsewhere in the province, including in Quebec City where Mayor Regis Labeaume easily won a fourth term.

Marc Demers was re-elected in Laval, as was Yves Levesque in Trois-Rivieres and Maxime Pedneaud-Jobin in Gatineau.

ValÃ©rie Plante stands on a Montreal street corner on Wednesday.

There was a surprise in Sherbrooke, however, where incumbent Bernard Sevigny lost the mayoral race to independent candidate Steve Lussier.

Some 858 municipal elections were held across the province, with over 8,000 mayor or councillor jobs up for grabs.

Of those, about half were already filled by election day by candidates who ran unopposed.

UPDATEâ€”We're now largest city in N. America with a female mayor! (And what a difference that's going to make for #Montreal) #polmtl #MTL2017 pic.twitter.com/byS116PG8E â€” Taras Grescoe (@grescoe) November 6, 2017

With a file from HuffPost Canada.

Also on HuffPost (en franÃ§ais):
TITLE: ValÃ©rie Plante To Become Montreal's First Female Mayor; Defeats Denis Coderre

Esta reflexiÃ³n la ha hecho despuÃ©s de que este domingo, un hombre acabase con la vida de, al menos, 27 personas en un tiroteo en Texas. El tiroteo de Sandy Hook fue en diciembre del aÃ±o 2012. Un joven de 20 aÃ±os matÃ³ a 20 niÃ±os y a seis adultos en una escuela primaria de Estados Unidos.

SUMMARY:
Myanmar State Counselor Aung San Suu Kyi smiles as she walks from a military helicopter after arriving at Sittwe airport on November 2, 2017, following a visit to Maungdaw in Myanmar's Rakhine State.
Suu Kyi, a Nobel Peace Prize winner, has faced heavy international criticism for not taking a higher profile in responding to what U.N. officials have called "ethnic cleansing" by the army.
Suu Kyi met a group of Muslim religious leaders, said Chris Lewa, of the Arakan Project monitoring group, citing Rohingya sources.
Myanmar?s Immigration Minister has expressed support for a controversial two-child limit on a Muslim minority group that opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi and the United Nations call discriminatory and a violation of human rights.
More than 4,000 crossed at different points on the river on Wednesday, Major Mohammed Iqbal, a Bangladesh security official in the southern district of Cox's Bazar, told Reuters.
TEXT:
Myanmar State Counselor Aung San Suu Kyi smiles as she walks from a military helicopter after arriving at Sittwe airport on November 2, 2017, following a visit to Maungdaw in Myanmar's Rakhine State.

ADVERTISEMENT

SITTWE, Myanmar - Myanmar's de facto leader, Aung San Suu Kyi, on Thursday urged people "not to quarrel" as she visited Rakhine State for the first time since a military crackdown that drove more than 600,000 Rohingya Muslims to flee the country.

Suu Kyi, a Nobel Peace Prize winner, has faced heavy international criticism for not taking a higher profile in responding to what U.N. officials have called "ethnic cleansing" by the army.

Myanmar has rejected the accusations of ethnic cleansing, saying its security forces launched a counter-insurgency operation after Rohingya militants attacked 30 security posts in northern Rakhine on Aug. 25.

On Thursday, amid heightened security, Suu Kyi boarded a military helicopter at Sittwe, the capital of Rakhine State, to be taken to Maungdaw, one of the districts worst hit by the violence.

Suu Kyi met a group of Muslim religious leaders, said Chris Lewa, of the Arakan Project monitoring group, citing Rohingya sources.

"She only said three things to the people - they should live peacefully, the government is there to help them, and they should not quarrel among each other."

"She only said three things to the people - they should live peacefully, the government is there to help them, and they should not quarrel among each other," Lewa said, quoting information from a religious leader who was present.

Rohingya began fleeing predominantly Buddhist Myanmar for neighbouring Bangladesh in late August to escape violence in the wake of a military counter-insurgency operation launched after Rohingya militants attacked security posts in Rakhine State.

Muslim children are seen at a refugee camp outside of Sittwe May 16, 2013. Myanmar?s Immigration Minister has expressed support for a controversial two-child limit on a Muslim minority group that opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi and the United Nations call discriminatory and a violation of human rights. Picture taken May 16, 2013. To match Interview MYANMAR ROHINGYA/ REUTERS/Soe Zeya Tun (MYANMAR - Tags: SOCIETY POLITICS)

A U.S. State Department delegation will be in Bangladesh on Friday and Saturday to discuss the humanitarian crisis and human rights concerns stemming from the crisis in Rakhine state.

The delegation will be led by Simon Henshaw, acting assistant secretary of state for the Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, the department said in a statement.

On Wednesday, Reuters photographers saw thousands of desperate Rohingya wade through shallows and narrow creeks between islands of the Naf river to reach neighbouring Bangladesh as the exodus begun two months ago was far from over.

Some had small boats or pulled makeshift rafts to get to Bangladesh on the river's western bank, but most walked, children cradled in their arms and the elderly carried on their backs, with sacks of belongings tied to staves on their shoulders.

Reaching the far side, some women and older people had to be pulled through the mud to reach dry land atop steep banks.

More than 4,000 crossed at different points on the river on Wednesday, Major Mohammed Iqbal, a Bangladesh security official in the southern district of Cox's Bazar, told Reuters.
TITLE: Aung San Suu Kyi Visits Rahkine For First Time Since Exodus Of 60,000 Rohingya Muslims

SUMMARY:
A young woman has opened up about her shocking ovarian cancer diagnosis, after she began to develop thick facial hair and didnâ€™t have a period for six months.
PCOS causes many small and harmless follicles to grow on the ovaries and has symptoms including irregular or no periods and excess body and facial hair.
Amy continued: â€œSeven weeks had passed and Iâ€™d had my first period in a year and I thought everything was dandy.
My periods had started at about 14, but after a few years they gave me very severe lower back pain and I developed bad facial hair.
Then they stopped not long after I turned 18.â€ Contacted about a post-biopsy appointment, Amy went alone, believing everything was fine, only to be told she had cancer.
TEXT:
A young woman has opened up about her shocking ovarian cancer diagnosis, after she began to develop thick facial hair and didnâ€™t have a period for six months. Amy Allen, then 18, of Berkhamsted, Hertfordshire, was due to start her first year of a psychology degree at York St Johnâ€™s University, when she saw her GP because her period had stopped. Not long after, she received the diagnosis. Now 21 and recently graduated, Amy said: â€œI was the first person in living memory in Yorkshire to be diagnosed with that type of ovarian tumour, a Sertoli-Leydig sex cord tumour. â€œI went to the hospital appointment alone and hearing the words, â€˜Itâ€™s cancerâ€™ was incredibly shocking.â€

PA Real Life Features Amy Allen (right) pictured with a friend.

Initially, Amy, the eldest of four children, was wrongly suspected of suffering from polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), as her symptoms were very similar. PCOS causes many small and harmless follicles to grow on the ovaries and has symptoms including irregular or no periods and excess body and facial hair. Recalling the moment her GP told her she needed further tests during freshersâ€™ week, Amy said: â€œThe doctor from home rang me to ensure I was getting checked out. My blood test results had revealed that my testosterone levels were 2.5 times higher than they should be, and my oestrogen levels were significantly lower.â€ Subsequent ultra-scan and MRI scans carried out at York Hospital in late 2014 indicated that Amy had a suspected cyst on her ovary. In March 2015, she had this biopsied, so it could be examined more closely. Amy continued: â€œSeven weeks had passed and Iâ€™d had my first period in a year and I thought everything was dandy. My periods had started at about 14, but after a few years they gave me very severe lower back pain and I developed bad facial hair. Then they stopped not long after I turned 18.â€ Contacted about a post-biopsy appointment, Amy went alone, believing everything was fine, only to be told she had cancer. She recalled: â€œThe doctors and nurses were so nice. They explained everything and we had a laugh about the rarity and excitement of the type of tumour â€“ the first one to be diagnosed in Yorkshire. â€œIf I hadnâ€™t laughed I would have cried.â€ But she saved her tears until she could call her housemates, when she sobbed down the phone. â€œGetting the diagnosis was the scariest day of my life and a memory that will stay with me for a while,â€ she admitted. â€œAt 19 years old and coming towards the end of my first year of university, cancer was not something I thought Iâ€™d personally have to go through.â€
TITLE: Graduate Reveals How Missed Period And Facial Hair Turned Out To Be Signs Of Rare Cancer

POLITIQUE - "J'ai des doutes"... Depuis quelques semaines, Marine Le Pen parcourt la France dans l'espoir de renouveler un parti fondÃ© il y a plus de 45 ans. Samedi 4 novembre, cette "tournÃ©e de refondation" a fait une halte Ã  Fontenay-TrÃ©signy, en Seine-et-Marne, oÃ¹ environ 500 sympathisants frontistes se sont rÃ©unis pour un dÃ©jeuner-dÃ©bat avec leur prÃ©sidente.

L'occasion pour Marine Le Pen de s'inscrire dans la continuitÃ© d'un discours sans ambiguÃ¯tÃ© sur ses thÃ¨mes de prÃ©dilection (terrorisme, immigration, identitÃ©, etc.), mais aussi d'appeler sa famille politique Ã  une nouvelle "culture de gouvernement" et non de simple opposition. "Cela passe par une rÃ©volution culturelle interne, Ã  laquelle je vous exhorte. Ne plus se contenter de commenter l'actualitÃ©, mais de construire, Ã  tous les Ã©chelons, de vÃ©ritables contre-projets", a expliquÃ© la prÃ©sidente du FN devant les Ã©lecteurs et plusieurs cadres du parti.

Mais, au fait, Marine Le Pen est-elle Ã  l'abri de cette "refondation" ? Lors de ce rassemblement, si nous avons rencontrÃ© une majoritÃ© d'Ã©lecteurs toujours aussi fidÃ¨les Ã  leur prÃ©sidente, certains n'ont pas hÃ©sitÃ© Ã  exprimer leurs doutes, Ã  critiquer parfois durement leur prÃ©sidente ou mÃªme Ã  rÃ©clamer son dÃ©part face Ã  notre camÃ©ra, comme vous pouvez le voir dans la vidÃ©o tÃªte d'article. En 1914, quand les gÃ©nÃ©raux ont emmenÃ© l'armÃ©e franÃ§aise Ã  la dÃ©faite, ils ont Ã©tÃ© remplacÃ©s. Pascal, Ã©lecteur FN Ã  propos de Marine Le Pen

SUMMARY:
Storing your eggs in the fridge door will expose them to sudden temperature changes each time the door opens and closes, says food storage expert Vlatka Lake.
"The general consensus is to store eggs in the fridge, but not in the egg racks commonly found on the fridge door."
Egg safety in CanadaIn Europe, it's common to store eggs at room temperature, but because of differences in production practices, that is not advised in North America.

TEXT:
You know that handy egg rack on the door of your fridge?

Yeah, don't use it.

Storing your eggs in the fridge door will expose them to sudden temperature changes each time the door opens and closes, says food storage expert Vlatka Lake. And that will make them go rotten faster, Lake recently told The Sun.

Don't do this.

"When it comes to eggs, there is a huge debate on where they should be kept, with some saying in the fridge and others saying on the counter," Lake said. "The general consensus is to store eggs in the fridge, but not in the egg racks commonly found on the fridge door."

Egg safety in Canada

In Europe, it's common to store eggs at room temperature, but because of differences in production practices, that is not advised in North America.

Fresh eggs should always be stored in the fridge, and never frozen, according to Health Canada. They should never be kept at room temperature for more than two hours, whether they're raw or cooked, the agency added.

Article continues below video.

And as for their place in the fridge?

"Eggs should be refrigerated as soon as possible in the coldest section of the refrigerator (usually the body of the fridge)," Health Canada said.

Keeping them in their carton will also help protect eggs from damage, Health Canada said. The agency noted that eggs can sometimes be contaminated with salmonella and other bacteria that could cause food poisoning.

Also on HuffPost:
TITLE: This Is Why You Should Never Store Eggs In The Fridge Door
Fight the cancer

TEXT:
Martin Schulz will den SPD-Mitgliedern mehr Mitsprache bei Personalfragen einrÃ¤umen

In einem Reformpapier rechnet er auch mit dem eigenen Wahlkampf ab

"JÃ¼nger und weiblicher" sollte die SPD nach dem Debakel bei der Bundestagswahl werden. Zu sehen ist davon allerdings bisher wenig. Parteichef Martin Schulz drÃ¤ngt nun laut einem Medienbericht auf eine umfassende Reform der SPD.

Die Mitglieder sollen kÃ¼nftig in Personalfragen - auch auf Bundesebene - stÃ¤rker mitbestimmen kÃ¶nnen. Das stehe in einem entsprechenden Leitantrag fÃ¼r den Bundesparteitag im Dezember, berichtet der "Spiegel".

Ziel sei es, spÃ¤testens 2019 Ã¼ber den SPD-Vorsitz per Urwahl abstimmen zu lassen, zitiert das Nachrichtenmagazin Parteikreise. Bislang ist eine Urwahl nur fÃ¼r die Frage der Kanzlerkandidatur vorgesehen.

"Der Kanzlerkandidat und die SPD haben die Wahl verloren"

In dem Papier gehe Schulz auch Ã¼berraschend hart mit dem SPD-Wahlkampf ins Gericht. "Nicht die Medien, nicht die Demoskopen und auch nicht die politischen Gegner sind schuld an unserer Wahlniederlage", zitiert der "Spiegel" daraus.

"Der Kanzlerkandidat und die gesamte SPD haben diese Wahl verloren." Vielen WÃ¤hlern sei nicht klar gewesen, wofÃ¼r die SPD stehe.

Zudem habe es an einer klaren Botschaft an die WÃ¤hler gefehlt. Viele WÃ¤hler hÃ¤tten den Eindruck gehabt, "die SPD treibe jeden Tag eine 'neue Sau durch das Dorf', schreibe Schulz in dem Reformpapier.

"Eine verstÃ¤ndliche ErzÃ¤hlung, wo wir mit dem Land hinwollen, fehlt - und damit eine wesentliche Voraussetzung fÃ¼r echte Zukunftskompetenz", zitiert der "Spiegel" weiter.

Ruf nach Erneuerung

Schulz' Papier sei weder "revolutionÃ¤r", noch biete es ein "fertiges Konzept fÃ¼r den Wiederaufbau der SPD", kommentiert das Nachrichtenmagazin. Allerdings enthalte das Dokumente viele Anhaltspunkte, wie es fÃ¼r die Sozialdemokraten weitergehen kÃ¶nnte.

Zuletzt hatte Hamburgs BÃ¼rgermeister Olaf Scholz sich mit einem Papier in die Debatte um die Erneuerung der SPD eingemischt. Er forderte eine "schonungslose Betrachtung der Lage".

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: SPD am Scheideweg - Erneuern oder erodieren

"Ich fÃ¼hlte kaum Tritte und die, die ich bemerkte, waren sehr sanft â€“ es war nicht normalâ€œ, sagte sie dem amerikanischen Nachrichtenportal "USA Todayâ€œ.
SchlieÃŸlich konnte mithilfe von Spenden auch die App, die laut den GrÃ¼nderinnen auf wissenschaftlichen und medizinischen Erkenntnissen basiert, entwickelt werden.
Sie unterstÃ¼tzt die werdenden MÃ¼tter dabei, tÃ¤glich in einem bestimmten Zeitabschnitt die Bewegungen ihres Babys zu zÃ¤hlen und zu Ã¼berwachen.
Price hofft, dass sie mithilfe der App und AufklÃ¤rung der MÃ¼tter Ã¤hnliche Erfolge bei der Senkung der Totgeburtenrate erzielen kann.
Interessierte MÃ¼tter kÃ¶nnen sich die App auf der Webseite der Organisation kostenlos herunterladen.
TEXT:
Diese App von MÃ¼ttern hat in zehn Wochen drei Babys gerettet - mit einer ganz einfachen Methode. | DaniloAndjus via Getty Images

Emily Eekhoff bemerkte, dass sich ihr ungeborenes Baby plÃ¶tzlich anders in ihrem Bauch bewegt

Sie alarmierte die Ã„rzte gerade noch rechtzeitig und konnte so ihr Baby retten

Die App Count the Kicks half ihr dabei, zu merken, dass etwas mit ihrer Tochter nicht stimmte

Die junge Mutter Emily Eekhoff ist Ã¼berzeugt: Ohne eine App wÃ¤re ihr Baby jetzt nicht mehr am Leben.

Die 26-JÃ¤hrige aus Des Moines im US-Bundesstaat Iowa nutzte wÃ¤hrend ihrer Schwangerschaft die App Count the Kicks (auf Deutsch: ZÃ¤hlt die Tritte) - sie hilft MÃ¼ttern im letzten Trimester dabei, die AktivitÃ¤t ihrer Babys im Bauch zu Ã¼berwachen.

Wenn einer werdenden Mutter auffÃ¤llt, dass sich das Baby auf einmal ungewÃ¶hnlich still verhÃ¤lt, kann das auf gefÃ¤hrliche Komplikationen hinweisen.

Ohne die App und die Aufmerksamkeit ihrer Mutter hÃ¤tte Ruby nicht Ã¼berlebt

Als sich die hochschwangere Eekhoff vergangenen FrÃ¼hling eines Abends hinsetzte, um mithilfe der App die Bewegungen ihres Babys zu zÃ¤hlen, spÃ¼rte sie, dass etwas anders war als sonst. "Ich fÃ¼hlte kaum Tritte und die, die ich bemerkte, waren sehr sanft â€“ es war nicht normalâ€œ, sagte sie dem amerikanischen Nachrichtenportal "USA Todayâ€œ.

Auch Techniken, die das Baby im Bauch zu mehr Bewegungen animieren sollen, brachten keine VerÃ¤nderung. Beunruhigt fuhren die Eltern ins Krankenhaus. Dort stellten die Ã„rzte fest, dass das Baby in groÃŸen Schwierigkeiten war und der Mediziner Neil Mandsager, der auf Risikoschwangerschaften spezialisiert ist, leitete einen Not-Kaiserschnitt ein.

Denn bei der kleinen Ruby hatte sich die Nabelschnur dreimal um ihr Genick gewickelt. Die Ã„rzte sind der Meinung, dass sie so keinen Tag mehr im Bauch ihrer Mutter Ã¼berlebt hÃ¤tte. Doch dank der schnellen Hilfe hat es das kleine MÃ¤dchen auf die Welt geschafft - und entwickelt sich prÃ¤chtig.

Arzt Mandsager kennt die App und empfiehlt sie allen werdenden MÃ¼ttern: â€œDiese App ist ein schlagkrÃ¤ftiges Instrument fÃ¼r MÃ¼tter im letzten Trimester. Wir ermutigen alle MÃ¼tter, diese App herunterzuladen, wenn sie in der 28. Woche sind â€“ bei Risikoschwangerschaften auch gern schon ab der 26. Woche.â€œ

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Sie hat ihr Baby verloren - mit diesen Fotos macht eine junge Frau anderen Betroffenen Mut

"Wir wissen von drei Babys, die wir diesen Sommer gerettet habenâ€œ

Im Bundesstaat Iowa empfehlen in einer Ã¶ffentlichen Kampagne viele KrankenhÃ¤user und GynÃ¤kologen, die Bewegungen des Babys im Bauch zu zÃ¤hlen â€“ auch mithilfe von Count the Kicks, das man kostenlos downloaden kann.

Emily Price, GeschÃ¤ftsfÃ¼hrerin von Count the Kicks, sagte der HuffPost: "Wir wissen von drei Babys, die wir diesen Sommer gerettet haben, da ihre MÃ¼tter die App genutzt haben und zum Arzt gegangen sind, als ihnen VerÃ¤nderungen bei den Bewegungen ihrer Babys aufgefallen sind.â€œ

ZurÃ¼ck geht das Projekt auf fÃ¼nf Mutter, die alle aus Iowa stammen und eine Fehl- oder Totgeburt erlitten haben. Nach dieser traumatischen Erfahrung wollten die Frauen verhindern, dass andere Familien das gleiche Schicksal erleben mÃ¼ssen.

Die MÃ¼tter stieÃŸen bei der Recherche auf ein Projekt aus Norwegen: Dort konnte in mehreren KrankenhÃ¤usern nach einer Ã¶ffentlichen Gesundheitskampagne die Rate der Totgeburten um 30 Prozent gesenkt werden, wie mehrere Studien zeigen.

In der Kampagne wurde schwangeren Frauen nahegelegt, ab dem letzten Schwangerschaftsdrittel die Tritte ihrer Babys tÃ¤glich zu zÃ¤hlen und regelmÃ¤ÃŸig zu den Vorsorgeuntersuchungen zu gehen.

Die Rate der Totgeburten sank in Iowa um 23 Prozent

Davon inspiriert starteten die MÃ¼tter 2009 "Healthy Birth Dayâ€œ, eine Non-Profit-Organisation, die sich mit UnterstÃ¼tzung der Regierung in Iowa mit den KrankenhÃ¤usern und GynÃ¤kologen vernetzte und BroschÃ¼ren und Informationen an werdende MÃ¼tter verteilte.

SchlieÃŸlich konnte mithilfe von Spenden auch die App, die laut den GrÃ¼nderinnen auf wissenschaftlichen und medizinischen Erkenntnissen basiert, entwickelt werden. Sie unterstÃ¼tzt die werdenden MÃ¼tter dabei, tÃ¤glich in einem bestimmten Zeitabschnitt die Bewegungen ihres Babys zu zÃ¤hlen und zu Ã¼berwachen.

Bisher haben laut Price 45.000 Frauen die App heruntergeladen - weltweit. Am weitesten verbreitet ist Count the Kicks allerdings in Iowa.

Seit der EinfÃ¼hrung von Count the Kicks sank die Rate der Totgeburten in dem Bundesstaat um 26 Prozent â€“ einen Erfolg, den Price der Kampagne ihrer Organisation zuschreibt.

Die GeschÃ¤ftsfÃ¼hrerin sagt: "Manchmal ist das ZÃ¤hlen der Tritte im Bauch das einzige Anzeichen und das frÃ¼heste Anzeichen, das etwas schief lÃ¤uft.â€œ Bis zu sechzehn Babys wurden bisher mit dieser Methode gerettet, wie die Organisation berichtet.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Darf ich mich Mutter nennen?

2000 Sternenkinder pro Jahr

In Deutschland kommen auf 1000 Neugeborene 2,4 Totgeburten â€“ unser Land hat damit eine der niedrigsten Raten der Welt. Das bedeutet, dass es bei uns pro Jahr 2000 sogenannte Sternenkinder gibt.

Die Ursache dafÃ¼r, dass die Babys noch im Bauch der Mutter sterben, kÃ¶nnen Probleme mit der Plazenta oder der Nabelschnur sein - bei Ã¼ber 30 Prozent der FÃ¤lle bleibt der Grund allerdings unklar.

Zur Vorbeugung einer Totgeburt empfehlen die Ã„rzte auch bei uns, auf die Bewegungen des Kindes im Bauch zu achten und regelmÃ¤ÃŸig zur Vorsorge zu gehen. Bei vaginalen Blutungen sollten Schwangere sofort einen Arzt aufsuchen.

AufklÃ¤rung soll helfen, die Rate noch weiter zu senken

Nicht zu verwechseln sind Totgeburten mit Fehlgeburten - diese sind vor allem im ersten Trimester sehr hÃ¤ufig. Ã„rzte schÃ¤tzen, dass in Deutschland 30 Prozent der Schwangerschaften mit einer Fehlgeburt enden. Ursache sind dabei genetische StÃ¶rungen und fehlerhafte Zellteilungen beim Embryo, die eine Weiterentwicklung des Babys verhindern.

Dagegen kann die Methode des Tritte ZÃ¤hlens natÃ¼rlich leider nicht helfen. Sie richtet sich ausschlieÃŸlich an Schwangere im letzten Trimester. Die Hoffnung ist, dass die Ã„rzte das Baby in manchen FÃ¤llen â€“ wie bei Problemen mit der Nabelschnur - noch retten kÃ¶nnen, wenn die MÃ¼tter eine VerÃ¤nderung der Kindsbewegungen bemerken.

Wie in Deutschland ist die Zahl der Totgeburten in den USA etwas hÃ¶her als die Zahl der Kinder, die an dem PlÃ¶tzlichen Kindstod (SIDS) sterben. Hier haben zahlreiche AufklÃ¤rungsprogramme dabei geholfen, dass der Befund in den letzten Jahren gesunken ist â€“ in Deutschland in den letzten zwei Jahrzehnten sogar um etwa 90 Prozent.

Price hofft, dass sie mithilfe der App und AufklÃ¤rung der MÃ¼tter Ã¤hnliche Erfolge bei der Senkung der Totgeburtenrate erzielen kann.

Interessierte MÃ¼tter kÃ¶nnen sich die App auf der Webseite der Organisation kostenlos herunterladen.

(best)
TITLE: Eine App hat in zehn Wochen drei Babys gerettet - durch eine ganz einfache Methode

SUMMARY:
Lui â€“ ed Ã¨ anche questo in fondo un merito di Gabanelli â€“ non ci ha fatto sentire la sua mancanza a Report.
Nel panorama Rai l'assenza di Gabanelli si Ã¨ fatta invece sentire via via sempre di piÃ¹.
Ma la Rai non puÃ² perdere una professionista come Milena Gabanelli.
Si chiede alla Rai di non privarsi di una professionista del calibro di Milena Gabanelli.
Quel pubblico che la Rai vezzeggiava con lo slogan "Rai.
TEXT:
Quando Milena Gabanelli ha annunciato che avrebbe lasciato la direzione di Report, il programma che aveva creato vent'anni prima, abbiamo tutti avuto un sussulto.

Non accade spesso di vedere una giornalista con un posto sicuro e di grande visibilitÃ , alla conduzione di un programma che non ha smesso di crescere e mietere ascolti e riconoscimenti, dire "Sono stati vent'anni indimenticabili, grazie di tutto" e lasciare con fiducia la conduzione al co-autore che la affianca da dieci anni, Sigfrido Ranucci. Lui â€“ ed Ã¨ anche questo in fondo un merito di Gabanelli â€“ non ci ha fatto sentire la sua mancanza a Report.

Nel panorama Rai l'assenza di Gabanelli si Ã¨ fatta invece sentire via via sempre di piÃ¹.

Non era un segreto per nessuno che avrebbe voluto misurarsi con l'informazione digitale. Ma il sito di Rai News, che pure ambiva a modellarsi su quello di Bbc News â€“ una testata digitale con cui collaborano tutti/e i/le giornalisti/e della Bbc, al di lÃ  delle produzioni radiotelevisive in cui operano â€“ rischia di restare una Cinquecento che sogna di essere una Rolls Royce, un doppione digitale dei servizi esistenti, con una redazione ristretta, tempi incerti, futuro nebuloso.

Gabanelli ha allora proposto un format che ancora una volta coglie un trend nuovo nell'informazione: data journalism, giornalismo basato sui dati. Ovvero una striscia quotidiana di 4 minuti, dopo il tiggÃ¬ delle 20, per raccontare un fatto con i numeri. Quattro minuti in cui coniugare innovazione e maturitÃ  professionale, quella acquisita in vent'anni di Report.

All'ennesimo rifiuto, condito con la controproposta irricevibile di tornare a Report, Ã¨ arrivata la lettera di dimissioni, che diventeranno operative il prossimo 15 novembre.

Ma la Rai non puÃ² perdere una professionista come Milena Gabanelli. PerchÃ© allora avrebbero ragione quelli che pensano che per una come lei non c'Ã¨ posto nella "Rai-carrozzone al servizio della politica".

Ci piace immaginare la Rai innanzitutto come un servizio pubblico. Ci piace anche immaginare che il pubblico in questi vent'anni ha ampiamente dimostrato, a suon di indici di ascolto, che il posto di Milena Gabanelli Ã¨ alla Rai. Rinunciare a lei sarebbe un tragico, colpevole, autogol.

Per questo l'Associazione 99% ha lanciato questa petizione.

Si chiede alla Rai di non privarsi di una professionista del calibro di Milena Gabanelli.

Inoltre, si chiede alla Rai, come utenti del servizio pubblico radiotelevisivo pagato con il canone di abbonamento da noi tutti cittadini e cittadine, di affidare a Milena Gabanelli una striscia d'informazione quotidiana, a completamento e integrazione dei servizi d'informazione giÃ  in onda, cosÃ¬ come la giornalista ha proposto. Quattro minuti di fatti raccontati attraverso i numeri.

Una simile concessione non potrÃ  essere letta come una resa dei vertici aziendali alle richieste di una sua dipendente, ma come l'accoglimento di una richiesta del pubblico. Quel pubblico che la Rai vezzeggiava con lo slogan "Rai. Di tutti, di piÃ¹" e a cui aveva promesso di essere "Molto di piÃ¹ che una Tv".

Senza Milena Gabanelli rischia di essere davvero molto di meno.
TITLE: La RAI trovi quattro minuti per Milena Gabanelli

SUMMARY:
â€“ this is the OODD Guide to Eating Out with a Baby.
Donâ€™t let your baby making normal baby sounds ruin your meal.
Late food, loud customers, stroppy staff and over-crowded eating areas are no fun with a baby.
In many ways, with a bit of effort, eating in can be just as much â€˜funâ€™ as eating out.
***If you have any advice on Eating Out With a Baby, keep it to yourself.
TEXT:
It used to be your favourite thing to do (well, one of your favourites at least) but now the mere mention of it sends shivers down your spine.

No, Iâ€™m not talking about going to see the latest Batman movie (who says Iâ€™m not topical?) â€“ this is the OODD Guide to Eating Out with a Baby.

Trust me, this will change your life *.

*It probably wonâ€™t.

There comes a time in every parentâ€™s life when sitting in your nappy-scented home, for hour after hour, cleaning up sick, sterilizing bottles and watching Judge Rinder, is no longer is the fun it once was. Itâ€™s at this point that the idea of taking your child to eat in a restaurant first crosses your mind.

Yet youâ€™re reticent, with good reason.

What will the baby do?

Will it scream?

Will it do an explosive poo?

Will it do both?

Will it stare (like a miniature psychopath) at a frail old lady â€“ putting her off her soup?

And then thereâ€™s the other diners to think ofâ€¦

Will they be friendly?

Will they glare?

Will they complain to the management because of the noise?

Will they form a mob to have you ejected?

All of this potential stress is often enough to stop parents from leaving the confines of their homes. Donâ€™t let this happen to you!

Hereâ€™s my advice on how to Eat Out with a Baby.

1: Donâ€™t be an arsehole

The arrival of a baby in a restaurant is never EVER EVER going to make its parents popular. Weâ€™ve all been there. You go out for a quiet meal, perhaps in the hope of it going so well that you skip dessert, and next thing you know a family who look like theyâ€™d struggle to fill out a Jeremy Kyle Show application form arrives at the next table with their screaming feral offspring. Your meal is ruined â€“ you eat quickly and call for the bill. The family on the next table, however, are having a great time.

Donâ€™t be that family.

A little consideration for your fellow diners goes a long way. Itâ€™ll make your meal a lot more pleasant to know everyone else in the room isnâ€™t hating your guts.

2: Donâ€™t be too nice

Trying to be considerate to other diners is all very well â€“ but donâ€™t be crippled by it. Children make noise, itâ€™s as simple as that. As long as you appear to be making attempts to minimize the chaos youâ€™re doing your job. Youâ€™re not going to have a silent meal, itâ€™s impossible. Donâ€™t let your baby making normal baby sounds ruin your meal. You need a break too.

3: Be prepared

If youâ€™re properly prepared then the whole â€˜eating outâ€™ experience will be infinitely easier. That said, for many new parents, leaving the house wearing two matching shoes can be a struggle, so letâ€™s not set our sights too high here!

Itâ€™s totally possible to get through a meal with ease, by timing it to coincide with your babyâ€™s naptime. Bring essentials like milk and their favourite toys to ease any transition periods. That said, even the most prepared person in the world might find themselves in a restaurant with a baby who suddenly refuses to play ball.

4: Lower your standards

Do you like eating out at nice restaurants? Sorry, but those days are over. From now on youâ€™ll be dining in places that have â€˜Happyâ€™, â€˜Bigâ€™ & â€˜Wackyâ€™ in their titles. The food is undeniably crap, the tables are sticky and thereâ€™s a constant whiff of vomit, but youâ€™ll feel so much more relaxed in these places. Why? Well, for one thing, thereâ€™ll always be another kid doing exactly what you were dreading. So, if your child does melt down, itâ€™s unlikely anyone will notice.

NB: A bit of advice, never eat from a buffet bar in one of these establishments. They are are at the perfect height for little (snotty) hands to reach and play with the food â€“ before putting in back.

5: Go Early

Visiting a restaurant during peak times will put you in line for a whole heap of pain. Late food, loud customers, stroppy staff and over-crowded eating areas are no fun with a baby.

Perhaps consider going for your meal early or late? Dinner at 2 am is sure to leave you with the place to yourself. If this is too extreme find out when an establishment starts serving food and be there on the dot. A Sunday Roast at 1030 am may seem weird, but itâ€™s far a more relaxed than eating it at 1 pm like everyone else.

6: Be ready with comebacks

Having a few witty retorts to use with the inevitable malcontents youâ€™ll experience will make your trip much easier. When you find Clive and Norma moaning about the noise youâ€™re making, glaring from behind their copies of The Mail On Sunday, be sure to respond appropriately. Loudly shouting phrases such as: â€œHe may be still infectious, Iâ€™m not sure!â€ and â€œIâ€™ll take him outside to change his nappy on the bonnet of that Lexusâ€ will leave you feeling far more relaxed.

7: Other options

Perhaps, if you feel going out to eat with your baby is just too much stress, you could make a meal at home feel like youâ€™re in a restaurant. Consider inviting some strangers into your home to glare in your direction, as you eat cold, substandard food. In many ways, with a bit of effort, eating in can be just as much â€˜funâ€™ as eating out.

***

If you have any advice on Eating Out With a Baby, keep it to yourself. Nobody likes a know-it-all!

Still Sinkingâ€¦

The Out Of Depth Dad

@Outofdepth_dad

TITLE: The OODD Guide to Eating Out with a Baby

SUMMARY:
Police are investigating after fire ripped through an inner Sydney factory overnight.
Police and emergency services were called to the premises on Victoria Road at Marrickville after reports of a fire about 9pm Friday.
An investigation is underway after a huge blaze ripped through a #Marrickville factory last night.
Traffic diversions are in place due to a factory fire in Marrickville.
#9News pic.twitter.com/ucryztNTt6 November 3, 2017A number of traffic diversions were put in place due to the incident, with Victoria Road closed between Sydenham Road and Enmore.
TEXT:
Police are investigating after fire ripped through an inner Sydney factory overnight.

Police and emergency services were called to the premises on Victoria Road at Marrickville after reports of a fire about 9pm Friday.

An investigation is underway after a huge blaze ripped through a #Marrickville factory last night. @7NewsSydney pic.twitter.com/Q8AYKJEw6N â€” Natasha Squarey (@NatashaSquarey) November 3, 2017

Fire fighters rushed to the scene and extinguished the blaze, with no evacuations needed.

Twenty-five firefighters and three trucks battled the fire from three sides of the building. Authorities couldn't get inside the factory because the fire was too fierce.

Traffic diversions are in place due to a factory fire in Marrickville. #9News pic.twitter.com/ucryztNTt6 November 3, 2017

A number of traffic diversions were put in place due to the incident, with Victoria Road closed between Sydenham Road and Enmore.

Police are urging anyone with information in relation to the blaze to call Crime Stoppers.
TITLE: Police Ask For Public's Help After Fire Rips Through Sydney Factory

SUMMARY:
The 31-year-old Army soldier pleaded guilty to desertion and misbehavior before the enemy last month, calling his actions "inexcusable."
Experts also testified during the trial that Bergdahl provided a "gold mine" of actionable intelligence for the U.S. military once he was recovered.
In a statement released after the trial, Bergdahl expressed his gratitude to everyone who searched for him in 2009, "especially those who heroically sustained injuries."
Trump called Bergdahl a "traitor" at least 45 times while he was campaigning, often imagining gruesome death scenarios while he did so.
During an Iowa campaign appearance in 2015, for instance, Trump said Bergdahl should be "thrown out of an airplane without a parachute."
TEXT:
A Fort Bragg military judge has sentenced Bowe Bergdahl to a dishonorable discharge, fined him $10,000 and reduced his rank to that of private from sergeant but did not sentence him to any time in prison.

The 31-year-old Army soldier pleaded guilty to desertion and misbehavior before the enemy last month, calling his actions "inexcusable."

Bergdahl left his post while on duty in Afghanistan's Paktika province in 2009 and got lost, only to be captured by the Taliban two or three hours later. He spent the next five years enduring torture in captivity and attempted to escape 15 times.

Experts also testified during the trial that Bergdahl provided a "gold mine" of actionable intelligence for the U.S. military once he was recovered. His detailed descriptions of life in captivity led to greatly improved methods for other troops looking to evade and escape the enemy.

"I was captured by the enemy against my will," Bergdahl told the hearing last month. "At the time I had no intention of causing search and recovery operations. ... It's very inexcusable."

In a statement released after the trial, Bergdahl expressed his gratitude to everyone who searched for him in 2009, "especially those who heroically sustained injuries."

He and his defense team also levelled strong criticism against President Donald Trump, who repeatedly attacked Bergdahl while campaigning last year, which they said harmed his chances of a fair trial.

"President Trump's unprincipled effort to stoke a lynch-mob atmosphere while seeking our Nation's highest office has cast a dark cloud over the case," the statement read. "Every American should be offended by his assault on the fair administration of justice and disdain for basic constitutional rights."

Trump called Bergdahl a "traitor" at least 45 times while he was campaigning, often imagining gruesome death scenarios while he did so. During an Iowa campaign appearance in 2015, for instance, Trump said Bergdahl should be "thrown out of an airplane without a parachute."

Trump responded to the sentencing in a tweet, calling it "a complete and total disgrace to our Country and to our Military."
TITLE: Bowe Bergdahl Avoids Jail In Army Desertion Case

SUMMARY:
As well as feeling isolated themselves, many parents worry that their children are suffering from loneliness, it suggests.
Action for Children, which commissioned the survey, said that loneliness can have a â€œdevastating impactâ€ on children and families.
More than two in five (43.8%) say they sometimes worry that their children are lonely, with a further 16.4% saying they often worry about this.
The survey was conducted to mark the launch of the charityâ€™s month-long partnership with the Jo Cox Commission on loneliness.
Action for Children Action for Children chief executive Sir Tony Hawkhead said more need to be done to address the â€œepidemicâ€ of loneliness.
TEXT:
Parenthood leaves many mothers and fathers feeling lonely or â€œcut offâ€ from family and friends, according to a poll. As well as feeling isolated themselves, many parents worry that their children are suffering from loneliness, it suggests. Action for Children, which commissioned the survey, said that loneliness can have a â€œdevastating impactâ€ on children and families.

Action For Children/PA The charity is working with the Jo Cox Commission

The poll, which questioned around 2,000 UK parents, found that nearly one in four (24.3%) say being lonely is a problem for them, with a further 27.6% saying it has been a problem in the past. And one in four (25.1%) said they have often felt cut off from friends and other support since becoming a parent for the first time, with 8.9% saying they always feel this way. One mother, Haley Minns, 34, from Hunstanton, Norfolk, said that becoming a parent was a â€œtotally different experience to what I expectedâ€. â€œIâ€™d thought I would be at my happiest, but actually it was so hard. I couldnâ€™t get out the house because I was so anxious,â€ she said. â€œAll my friends had babies at the same time, but to me, it felt like they were all doing better than me and I just shut myself off.â€

Philip Toscano/PA One mother said she found it hard to get out of the house after having a baby, because she felt so anxious.

Around one in five (20.5%) of those polled admitted that they have felt lonely in the last week, with around one in six (17.3%) saying they have experienced this in the last month. More than two in five (43.8%) say they sometimes worry that their children are lonely, with a further 16.4% saying they often worry about this. The survey was conducted to mark the launch of the charityâ€™s month-long partnership with the Jo Cox Commission on loneliness.

Action for Children Action for Children chief executive Sir Tony Hawkhead said more need to be done to address the â€œepidemicâ€ of loneliness.
TITLE: Charity Warns Of â€˜Devastating Impactâ€™ Of Loneliness On Parents And Children

TEXT:
Nach der Bundestagswahl fÃ¼hren CDU/CSU, B' 90/Die GrÃ¼nen und die FDP SondierungsgesprÃ¤che fÃ¼r eine mÃ¶gliche Regierungskoalition. Dabei wird es heute um die Themenfelder Innen, Sicherheit und Rechtsstaat gehen.

Auch die Legalisierung von Cannabis, die sich sowohl GrÃ¼ne als auch FDP ins Wahlprogramm geschrieben haben, wird Gegenstand der Verhandlungen sein. FÃ¼nf GrÃ¼nde, warum die Union sich nicht dagegen stellen sollte:

1. Jugendschutz im Mittelpunkt

Bei jungen Menschen, deren KÃ¶rper noch nicht voll ausgewachsen sind, ist der Konsum von Cannabis gefÃ¤hrlich: Es kann zu EntwicklungsverzÃ¶gerungen kommen und psychosoziale StÃ¶rungen, sogar Psychosen hervorrufen.

Weshalb dann die Legalisierung? Werden dadurch nicht mehr Kinder und Jugendliche kiffen? Das Gegenteil ist der Fall. In Deutschland ist es leichter Gras zu kaufen, als eine Flasche Wodka im Supermarkt. Denn dort gilt der Jugendschutz und an der Kasse wird der Ausweis kontrolliert - der Dealer wird danach jedoch nicht fragen.

Eine Legalisierung geht immer mit der kontrollierten Abgabe in zertifizierten Shops einher. Dadurch wird es fÃ¼r die Risikogruppe von Heranwachsenden schwerer an Gras zu kommen und sie werden besser vor den Gefahren des Konsums geschÃ¼tzt.

2. Schwarzmarkt austrocknen

Der Markt fÃ¼r Drogen in Deutschland wird auf ca. 2,5 Milliarden Euro pro Jahr geschÃ¤tzt. Der grÃ¶ÃŸte Teil davon entfÃ¤llt auf Cannabis. Die Vertriebswege entziehen sich der staatlichen Kontrolle. Verkauft wird in den dunklen Ecken der stÃ¤dtischen Parks oder in der Raucherecke hinter dem Bahnhof.

Die Dealer selbst sind hÃ¤ufig nur kleine RÃ¤dchen in einem System, das weit Ã¼ber sie selbst hinausgeht. Die Verlegung in legale Verkaufsstellen, in denen QualitÃ¤t und Reinheit der Substanzen sichergestellt sind, wÃ¼rde zu einer Austrocknung des Schwarzmarkts fÃ¼hren. Und damit den HintermÃ¤nnern eine wichtige Einnahmequelle entziehen.

Das wÃ¤re ein wichtiger und Ã¼berfÃ¤lliger Schritt um der organisierten KriminalitÃ¤t in Deutschland entgegenzuwirken. An gefÃ¤hrlichen Parallelstrukturen kann insbesondere die Rechtsstaatspartei CDU kein Interesse haben.

3. PrÃ¤vention und Steuereinnahmen

Findet der Verkauf nicht mehr beim Dealer im Park, sondern in einer zertifizierten Verkaufsstelle statt, so profitiert der Staat von den Steuereinnahmen. Allein die Umsatzsteuer von 19 % wÃ¼rde schÃ¤tzungsweise zusÃ¤tzliche Steuereinnahmen von rund 350 Millionen Euro generieren.

Eine zusÃ¤tzliche Verbrauchsteuer wie sie etwa fÃ¼r Zigaretten erhoben wird, verspricht weitere Einnahmen. Einen Teil davon sollte man fÃ¼r AufklÃ¤rung und PrÃ¤vention von Jugendlichen verwenden.

Informationen Ã¼ber die Risiken einer Droge sind abschreckender als Verbote. Das muss auch die CDU erkennen und sich fÃ¼r die Legalisierung aussprechen.

4. Konsum ja, Sucht nein

Etwa ein Drittel der 18-25-jÃ¤hrigen hat Cannabis schon einmal ausprobiert. RegelmÃ¤ÃŸig rauchen allerdings nur ca. 3,5 %. Zwar ist das Suchtpotenzial von Cannabisprodukten sehr gering und sie sind weniger schÃ¤dlich als die Volksdrogen Alkohol und Tabak.

Zum Vergleich: Etwa 3,3 Millionen Menschen sterben weltweit an Alkohol oder den Folgen des Konsums. Ein Todesfall durch Cannabis ist hingegen nicht bekannt.

Dennoch: Bei einigen Jugendlichen in dieser Gruppe wird man von einem problematischen Konsum sprechen mÃ¼ssen. Einer AbhÃ¤ngigkeit, die den schulischen und beruflichen Erfolg und das Sozialleben massiv beeintrÃ¤chtigen kann.

Diesen jungen Menschen muss man helfen, mit AufklÃ¤rung und Therapie. Ein Verbot der Droge hilft hier allerdings nicht: Die Angst vor einer Strafe hindert den AbhÃ¤ngigen, seine Sucht einzugestehen und Hilfe zu suchen.

Die NÃ¤chstenliebe gebietet es, Menschen in Not zu helfen, statt ihnen mit Strafe zu drohen: Auch die Christdemokraten sollten sich deshalb fÃ¼r die Legalisierung einsetzen.

5. Entlastung der Polizei

Wenn ich an einem lauen Sommerabend durch einen Park in Hamburg-EimsbÃ¼ttel laufe, riecht es nach Gras. Aber nicht kleinkriminelle Jugendliche rauchen da einen Joint, sondern FamilienvÃ¤ter oder Studentengruppen, die sich nach dem Picknick eine â€Feierabend-TÃ¼te" gÃ¶nnen.

Das GefÃ¼hl, dabei etwas Kriminelles zu tun, eine Straftat zu begehen, haben viele schon lange nicht mehr. Ein wirkungsloses Verbot muss aber schon zugunsten des Vertrauens in den Rechtsstaat abgeschafft werden.

Die Verfolgung von Gelegenheitskiffern ist nÃ¤mlich vor allem eines: Sinnlose BÃ¼rokratie. 145.000 Cannabis-Delikte werden jÃ¤hrlich erfasst. Etliche der Verfahren werden aber eingestellt und es kommt nicht zu einer Verurteilung.

Das verschwendet sowohl Arbeitszeit als auch Geld bei Polizei, Staatsanwaltschaft und den Gerichten. Und das obwohl die Justiz und die Polizisten besseres zu tun hÃ¤tten: Die Zahlen von EinbruchsdiebstÃ¤hlen steigen seit Jahren, die Zahl von gefÃ¤hrlichen oder schweren KÃ¶rperverletzungen stieg 2016 um fast 10 %.

Die Bundesregierung hat eine Verantwortung gegenÃ¼ber BÃ¼rgern und Polizisten. Echte Straftaten mÃ¼ssen verhindert und verfolgt werden.

Wenn CDU/CSU die Gesundheit von jungen Menschen am Herzen liegt, sie den Schwarzmarkt bekÃ¤mpfen und stattdessen zusÃ¤tzliche Steuereinnahmen nutzen mÃ¶chte, dann sollte sie sich fÃ¼r die Legalisierung einsetzen.

Je frÃ¼her sie kommt, desto schneller wird Suchtkranken geholfen und die StrafverfolgungsbehÃ¶rden hÃ¤tten endlich mehr Zeit, sich um richtige Verbrecher zu kÃ¼mmern. Jamaika bietet diese Chancen. Die Union sollte sie erkennen und nutzen.

____

Ihr habt auch ein spannendes Thema?

Die HuffPost ist eine Debattenplattform fÃ¼r alle Perspektiven. Wenn ihr die Diskussion zu politischen oder gesellschaftlichen Themen vorantreiben wollt, schickt eure Idee an unser Blog-Team unter blog@huffingtonpost.de.
TITLE: 5 GrÃ¼nde, warum auch CDU/CSU sich fÃ¼r die Cannabis-Legalisierung einsetzen sollte

In der Chenery Street in San Francisco steht ein Haus, das auf den ersten Blick wie ein gewÃ¶hnliches Reihenhaus aussieht. Doch dieser Eindruck tÃ¤uscht - hinter der Fassade des Hauses versteckt sich mehr. Das Haupthaus erstreckt sich auf drei GebÃ¤udeeinheiten, die an die StraÃŸe angrenzen.

Wenn man es betritt, kÃ¶nnte man meinen, in einer Villa aus einem James Bond-Film zu sein.

Das Haupthaus sieht nÃ¤mlich aus wie ein eindrucksvoller Palast â€“ mit Glasdach und einem Swimmingpool im Speisesaal. Im HauptgebÃ¤ude sind Buntglasfenster der ehemaligen Kirche Little Sisters of the Poor verbaut.

Das Haus wurde im Jahr 1987 erbaut

Das Glasdach der Villa lÃ¤sst sich zudem zur Seite fahren, damit die Sonnenstrahlen auch ungefiltert in das Innere des Hauses fallen kÃ¶nnen. Im HauptgebÃ¤ude befinden sich fÃ¼nf Schlafzimmer und genauso viele BÃ¤der. Im Obergeschoss der Villa hat man einen atemberaubenden Blick auf die Skyline von San Francisco.

Die Villa wurde im Jahr 1987 fÃ¼r den Werbefachmann Robert Pritikin gebaut. Derzeit steht das Anwesen zum Verkauf. Wer es haben mÃ¶chte, muss aber tief in die Tasche greifen: Das Anwesen kostet elf Millionen Dollar, also umgerechnet knapp zehn Millionen Euro.

SUMMARY:
Having a curved penis might have its benefits in the bedroom, but a new study has found that those who have this condition are at a higher risk of cancer.
Peyronie's disease is caused when scar tissue, known as plaque, forms inside the soft tissue of the penis causing it to curve when erect.
Additionally, these men have a 29 per cent greater risk of melanoma (a type of skin cancer) and a 40 per cent increased likelihood of stomach cancer.
Additionally, men who have Peyronie's disease running in their family may have cause for concern, since certain genes associated with the condition can also be found in urological cancers.
"It's not yet fully understood what causes Peyronie's disease and it's possible it shares some similar risk factors to cancer," Emma Shields, of the British charity Cancer Research U.K., told The Telegraph.
TEXT:
Having a curved penis might have its benefits in the bedroom, but a new study has found that those who have this condition are at a higher risk of cancer.

The research, which was published in the journal Fertility and Sterility, looked at more than 1.5 million men and found a significant connection between Peyronie's disease â€” a condition that causes men to have a bent, erect penis â€” and stomach, skin, and testicular cancers.

Peyronie's disease is caused when scar tissue, known as plaque, forms inside the soft tissue of the penis causing it to curve when erect. This can be painful for some and can even cause erectile dysfunction.

Though Medical News Today reports that the scar tissue in the penis is not cancerous, the new study found noteworthy connections to urological cancers.

After reviewing data from Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, Texas, researchers determined that those with Peyronie's disease, also known as a penile fibrosis, had an increased risk of testicular cancer by 40 per cent. Additionally, these men have a 29 per cent greater risk of melanoma (a type of skin cancer) and a 40 per cent increased likelihood of stomach cancer.

"Nobody has made these associations before," said urologist and study lead, Dr. Alexander Pastuszak, according to The Telegraph.

"We think this is important because these conditions are largely taken for granted," he continued. "While they're significant in the sexual and reproductive life-cycles of these patients, linking them to other disorders suggest that these men should be monitored for development of these disorders disproportionately in contrast to the rest of the population."

If you have a curved penis, don't panic just yet. According to Medical Daily, it's common for men to have a slight bend in their shaft, since the human body is rarely symmetrical.

Dr. Pastuszak also backed this up, saying, "A slight curve can be normal. There is some curvature in all penises."

Although penile fibrosis is most common among older men, specifically between the ages of 40 and 60, younger men can also get the disease. Risk factors include injury to the penis and genetics.

Additionally, men who have Peyronie's disease running in their family may have cause for concern, since certain genes associated with the condition can also be found in urological cancers.

"It's not yet fully understood what causes Peyronie's disease and it's possible it shares some similar risk factors to cancer," Emma Shields, of the British charity Cancer Research U.K., told The Telegraph.

Symptoms of Peyronie's disease include a significant bend in the shaft, flat lumps felt under the skin of the penis (which is the scar tissue), erection problems, a shortening of the penis, and pain, the Mayo Clinic reports.
TITLE: Men With Curved Penises Have A Greater Risk Of Cancer

TEXT:
Moe Szyslak has a message for Puerto Rico.

In a new short posted online Friday, the cranky bartender from â€œThe Simpsonsâ€ announced that the showâ€™s viewers had raised $25,000 to help with the islandâ€™s continuing recovery from Hurricane Maria.

He also zinged President Donald Trump.

Addressing San Juan Mayor Carmen YulÃ­n Cruz, Moe said he knew how it feels â€œwhen somebody comes and throws paper towels at youâ€ â€• a nod to Trump lobbing towels at locals as he visited the island in the aftermath of the natural disaster in September.

â€œIn my case it was flaming toilet paper but the principle is the same,â€ Moe added. â€œIt is humiliating.â€ He then ordered Barney to settle his bar tab, before encouraging viewers to continue to donate to the relief effort.

Cruz, who feuded with Trump after she complained about the federal response following the devastating storm, tweeted that she appreciated the gesture:

Thank you Moe for understanding how we feel. We have very little power but having @TheSimpsons in our corner fills our hearts with light. â€” Carmen YulÃ­n Cruz (@CarmenYulinCruz) November 4, 2017

SUMMARY:
ADVERTISEMENTNEW DELHI -- The all-powerful GST Council may consider lowering tax rates on a host of goods such as handmade furniture, plastic products and daily use items like shampoo, and simplify return filing rules in its meeting this week.
The council, headed by Finance Minister Arun Jaitley, is scheduled to meet on November 10 to consider lowering of the 28% GST rate on certain common use items, government officials said.
The council has been meeting every month since the Goods and Services Tax (GST) regime, which amalgamated over a dozen central and state taxes, was introduced on July 1.
Also tax rate on items like furniture, electric switches, plastic pipes could be relooked," an official said.
The GST Council, which comprises of representatives of all states, have already rationalised tax rates for over 100 items.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

NEW DELHI -- The all-powerful GST Council may consider lowering tax rates on a host of goods such as handmade furniture, plastic products and daily use items like shampoo, and simplify return filing rules in its meeting this week.

The council, headed by Finance Minister Arun Jaitley, is scheduled to meet on November 10 to consider lowering of the 28% GST rate on certain common use items, government officials said.

In further relief to small and medium enterprises, the panel is likely to rationalise tax rate in sectors where the total incidence of taxation has gone up because the goods were earlier either exempt from excise or was attracted lower VAT rates in the previous indirect tax regime.

The council has been meeting every month since the Goods and Services Tax (GST) regime, which amalgamated over a dozen central and state taxes, was introduced on July 1.

The meetings have resulted in an array of changes to ease compliance burden on businesses as well as provided relief to consumers.

"A rationalisation of items in the 28% tax bracket is expected. Most of the daily use items could be lowered to 18%. Also tax rate on items like furniture, electric switches, plastic pipes could be relooked," an official said.

All types of furniture attract a 28% tax under GST. Wooden furniture is handmade by unorganised sector artisans and is mostly used by middle class families and there have been demands for lowering tax incidence on them.

Also, some items of plastic attract 18% GST but goods like shower baths, sinks, wash basins, bidets, lavatory pans, seats and covers, flushing cisterns and similar sanitary ware of plastics attract 28% levy.

There is a need for rationalisation of tax rates on these items, officials said. The plastic manufacturers in their representation to the revenue department had said that 80% of the industry is in MSME category.

Besides, the GST rate on weighing machines, compressors may also be rationalised to 18% from 28%.

Officials said 90% of the manufacturers are from small and medium industries who in the pre-GST era were exempt from excise duty on manufactured value of less than Rs 1.5 crore.

Hence, such machines only attracted VAT of 14.5%. With regard to compressors, the total pre-GST incidence was 17.5% (12.5% excise duty and 5% VAT), they said stressing on need to rationalise the tax incidence.

The GST Council, which comprises of representatives of all states, have already rationalised tax rates for over 100 items. The Council has last month approved an Approach Paper to be followed by the fitment committee while deciding on future rate revisions.

Under GST various goods and services have been bracketed in 5, 12, 18 and 28%. GST has subsumed over a dozen taxes, including excise, service tax and VAT, and transformed India into a single market.
TITLE: GST Council May Consider Lowering Tax Rates On Common Goods Like Plastic Products And Shampoo
